GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 31.01 APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall apply alike to all officers and
employees of the village, regardless of the time of the creation of the office
or position or the time of the appointment of the officer or employee.
(`95 Code, § 31.01)
§ 31.02 ELECTIONS FOR MUNICIPAL OFFICES.
   Elections for municipal offices shall be held as provided by statute and
shall be at the time prescribed by the statute.
(`95 Code, § 31.02)
§ 31.03 BOND.
   (A)   Bond may be required. Every officer, employee and agent shall, if
required by the Board of Trustees, upon entering upon the duties of his or her
office, give a bond in such amount and with such sureties as may be determined
by the Board of Trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
duties of his or her office or position.
   (B)   Type of corporate surety bond when required. Whenever a surety bond to
indemnify the village is required as a prerequisite to exercising the duties of
any office or position or to the issuance of a license or permit or for the
exercise of any special privilege, the surety on such bond shall be a
corporation licensed and authorized to do business in the state as a surety
company, in the absence of specific provision to the contrary by ordinance.
   (C)   Securing additional surety on bond to indemnify village. Whenever in
the opinion of the Board of Trustees additional surety may be needed on any
bond to indemnify the village against loss or liability because of the
insolvency of the existing surety or for any other reason, the Board of
Trustees may order a new surety to be secured for such bond. If such new surety
is not procured within ten days from the time such order is transmitted to the
principal on the bond, or his or her assignee, the Board of Trustees shall
declare the bond to be void, and thereupon such principal or assignee, shall be
deemed to have surrendered the privilege or position as condition of which the
bond was required.
(`95 Code, § 31.03)
§ 31.04 POWERS OF ARREST FOR CERTAIN OFFICERS.
   The Village President, members of the Board of Trustees, as well as every
member of the Police Department, are hereby declared to be conservators of the
peace with such powers to make arrests as are given to conservators of the
peace by statute.
(`95 Code, § 31.04)
§ 31.05 OATH OF OFFICE.
   Every officer of the village shall, before entering upon his or her duties,
take the oath prescribed by statute.
(`95 Code, § 31.05)
§ 31.06 RECORDS TO BE OPEN FOR INSPECTION BY PRESIDENT OR BOARD OF TRUSTEES.
   All records kept by any officer of the village shall be open to inspection
by the President, or any member of the Board of Trustees at all reasonable
times, whether or not such records are required to be kept by statute or
ordinance.
(`95 Code, § 31.06)
§ 31.07 DISPOSITION OF MONIES RECEIVED BY OFFICERS.
   Every officer of the village shall at least once each month turn over all
money received by him or her in his or her official capacity, to the
Comptroller with a statement showing the source from which the same was
received.
(`95 Code, § 31.07)
§ 31.08 SALARIES.
   All officers and employees of the village shall receive such salary as may
be from time to time provided by ordinance or resolution.
(`95 Code, § 31.08) (Ord. 92-39, passed 12-16-92; Am. Ord. 05-40, passed 9-28-
05; Am. Ord. 05-62, passed 12-21-05)
§ 31.09 DELIVERY OF BOOKS AND RECORDS TO SUCCESSORS.
   Every officer and employee of the village, upon the expiration of his or her
term for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his or her successor all books
and records which may be the property of the village, and if no successor has
been appointed within one week after the termination of office, such property
shall be delivered to the Village Clerk or Village Treasurer.
(`95 Code, § 31.09)
§ 31.10 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   New employees.  
      (1)   Any person newly hired on or after the effective date of this
section as a non-probationary full-time employee of the village, to be employed
in any department operated by the village, shall be a bona fide resident of the
village, maintaining his or her permanent domicile within the village limits
for the duration of his or her employment.
      (2)   However, if, at the date of hiring, the person maintains his or her
permanent domicile outside the village limits, he or she shall have a period of
one year from the date of hiring within which to establish his or her permanent
domicile within the village.
   (B)   New probationary employees.
      (1)   Any person newly hired on or after the effective date of this
section as a probationary employee of the village, to be employed on a
probationary basis in any department operated by the village, shall be a bona
fide resident of the village, maintaining his or her permanent domicile within
the village limits for the duration of the probationary period, and continuing
for the duration of regular full- time employment.
      (2)   However, if, as of the date of hiring as a probationary employee,
the person maintain his or her domicile outside the village limits, he or she
shall have a period of one year from the date of the successful completion of
the probationary period within which to establish his or her permanent domicile
within the village.
   (C)   Appointed department heads. 
      (1)   Any person newly appointed to the position of department head of
any department operated by the village shall be a bona fide resident of the
village, maintaining his or her permanent domicile within the village limits
for the duration of his or her appointment.
      (2)   However, if, at the time of appointment, the person maintains his
or her permanent domicile outside the village limits, he or she shall have a
period of one year from the date of appointment within which to establish his
or her permanent domicile within the village.
   (D)   Current probationary employees.
      (1)   Any person employed by the village who is serving a probationary
period as of the effective date of this section, shall be a bona fide resident
of the village maintaining his or her permanent domicile within the village
limits for the duration of the probationary period, and continuing for the
duration of regular full-time employment.
      (2)   However, if, as of the effective date of this section, the
probationary employee maintains his or her domicile outside the village limits,
he or she shall have a period of one year from the date of the successful
completion of the probationary period within which to establish his or her
permanent domicile within the village.
   (E)   Current non-probationary employees and appointees.
      (1)   All persons currently employed as of the effective date of this
section as non-probationary police officers and firefighters shall each be
subject, during the period of service, to the residency requirements which were
in effect in the village at the date he or she entered service upon the
successful completion of his or her probationary period, unless less
restrictive requirements were subsequently enacted in which case the less
restrictive requirements shall control, all as provided by the Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners Act, ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 10-2.1-6.
      (2)   All other persons currently employed as of the effective date of
this section as non- probationary full-time employees of the village shall be
subject, during the period of employment, to the residency requirements in
effect in the village at the date he or she was first hired as a non-
probationary full-time employee, unless less restrictive requirements were
subsequently enacted, in which case the less restrictive requirements shall
control.
      (3)   All other persons currently employed as of the effective date of
this section who were first employed by the village on a probationary basis
shall be subject, during the period of employment, to the residency
requirements in the village at the date of the successful completion of the
probationary period, unless less restrictive requirements were subsequently
enacted, in which case, the less restrictive requirements shall control.
      (4)   All persons appointed as department heads as of the effective date
of this section shall be subject, during the period of this current
appointment, to any residency requirements which were made as a condition of
that appointment.
   (F)   Annual statement. All full-time employees and department head
appointees shall be required to file annually with the Village Clerk a
statement verifying the address of his or her permanent domicile.
   (G)   Exclusions. Divisions (A) through (F) of this section shall not apply
to any person hired or appointed who is supplying services on a limited
contractual basis and who is actually in the employ of another governmental
unit and/or private organization; or where such employment or office requires
special technical training, skill and knowledge.
   (H)   Penalty.  
      (1)   Any employee or department head appointee, except an employee of
the Police and Fire Departments appointed by the Board of Police and Fire
Commissioners, who shall fail to abide by the terms of the residency
requirements set forth in this section, shall be notified in writing by the
Village Clerk. The notice shall be delivered personally to the employee,
informing him or her of the failure to abide by the terms of the residency
requirements and setting the matter for hearing before the President and Board
of Trustees within ten days.
      (2)   At the hearing, the employee shall have an opportunity to be heard,
and to be represented by counsel.
      (3)   If, after the hearing, the President and Board of Trustees, by a
majority vote, determine that the employee is not a bona fide resident and
there is not just reason for the employee's failure to abide by the terms of
the residency requirements, then the President and Board of Trustees may order
that the employees be dismissed.
      (4)   Any employee of the Police or Fire Department who is appointed by
the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, and who fails to abide by the terms
of the residency requirements set forth herein, shall be subject to
disciplinary procedures pursuant to ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 10-2.1-17.
   (I)   Extensions.
      (1)   Upon written request of any employee or department head appointee,
the Village President may extend, for a period not exceeding 30 days, the time
within which the person is to establish his or her permanent domicile in the
village, upon good cause shown by the employee or appointee for documented
extenuating circumstances.
      (2)   In no event shall the Village President consider more than three
such requests from any individual employee or appointee for a total extension
of 90 days.
      (3)   Any written requests for extensions beyond 90 days shall be
submitted to the Board of Trustees who shall conduct a hearing on the request.
At the hearing the employee shall have an opportunity to be heard regarding the
extenuating circumstances.
      (4)   After the hearing, the President and Board of Trustees, by majority
vote, shall determine if the request for extension should be granted.
(`95 Code, § 31.10) (Ord. 89-1, passed 1-25-89)
§ 31.11 REGULATION OF POLITICAL ACTIVITIES BY AND GIFTS TO VILLAGE OFFICERS AND
EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   The regulations of Sections 5-15 (ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, §§ 5-15) and
Article 10 (ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, §§ 10-10 through 10-40) of the State Officials
and Employees Ethics Act (ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, §§ 1-1 et seq.) (hereinafter
referred to as the “Act” in this section) are hereby adopted by reference and
made applicable to the officers and employees of this governmental entity to
the extent required by ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 70-5.
   (B)   The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or
accepted under the Act, by any officer or any employee is hereby prohibited.
    (C)   The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to
an officer or employee is hereby prohibited.
   (D)   The participation in political activities prohibited under the Act, by
any officer or employee is hereby prohibited.
   (E)   For purposes of this section, the terms OFFICER and EMPLOYEE shall be
defined as set forth in ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 70-5(c).
   (F)   This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing
enactment which regulates the conduct of officers and employees. To the extent
that any such existing ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this
section, however, the provisions of this section shall prevail in accordance
with the provisions of ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 70-5(a).
   (G)   Any amendment to the Act that becomes effective after the effective
date of this section shall be incorporated into this section by reference and
shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of
gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes
its provisions optional for adoption shall not be incorporated into this
section by reference without formal action by this governmental entity.
   (H)   A violation of any provision of this section shall be punished through
the bringing of a quasi-criminal judicial complaint by an attorney chosen in
the manner provided by law for this governmental entity. That prosecutor shall
utilize prosecutorial discretion in enforcing this section and may seek such
penalties for a violation of this section as are allowed to be sought under
local or state law.
   (I)   The penalties for violations of this section shall be the same as
those penalties set forth in ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 50-5 for similar violations
of the Act.
   (J)   (1)   If the Illinois Supreme Court declares the Act unconstitutional
in its entirety, then this section shall be repealed as of the date that the
Illinois Supreme Court’s decision becomes final and not subject to any further
appeals or rehearings.
      (2)   If the Illinois Supreme Court declares part of the Act
unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the Act,
or does not address the remainder of the Act, then the remainder of the Act as
adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that
part of this section relating to the part of the Act found unconstitutional
shall be deemed repealed without further action by this governmental entity.
(Ord. 04-19, passed 4-28-04)
§ 31.12 FINANCIAL INDEBTEDNESS.
   All officers and employees of the village are to at all times remain in good
standing with any accounts or sums due and owing to the village; no officer of
employee should at any time be in arrearage on any financial obligation to the
village. No person is eligible for election, appointment, or employment with
the village who has financial obligations in arrearage with the village. Past
due financial obligations by an officer or employee to the village shall
subject the person to possible disciplinary action, including dismissal.
(Ord. 02-39, passed 9-25-02)
§ 31.13 PERSONAL USE OF VILLAGE’S ADDRESS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   Village employees shall not use the village address as their address
for personal purposes, except as provided herein.
   (B)   Police officers and fire investigators may provide the village address
as their home address only for purposes of vehicle registration and titles in
accordance with ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3-405(a)(1).
   (C)   Any correspondence that a village employee receives at the address of
the village, other than correspondence from the Illinois Secretary of State’s
office to police officers and fire investigators, will be presumed to be work-
related and may be subject to being opened and reviewed by village staff. The
village will presume that such materials are not confidential and are related
to village business and will open the mail in the regular course of business.
(Ord. 03-57, passed 11-12-03)
§ 31.14 ALCOHOL AND DRUG POLICY.
   (A)   The village hereby adopts by reference, as if fully set forth herein,
a zero tolerance policy for workplace drug and alcohol use. The Village of
Bellwood Alcohol and Drug Policy is set forth in Exhibit A to Ordinance 06-45.
   (B)   The alcohol and drug policy shall become a part of the policies and
procedures which govern the employment of village employees and shall be
enforced by village officials and administrators.
   (C)   The village is hereby authorized to perform law enforcement activities
on private property in accordance with executed agreements or as otherwise
permitted by law.
   (D)   The alcohol and drug policy shall not apply to those employees who are
parties to current collective bargaining agreements which contain alcohol and
drug provisions therein.
(Ord. 06-45, passed 4-12-06)
§ 31.15 MANDATORY AND VOLUNTARY PAYROLL WITHHOLDINGS.
   (A)   The following benefits and payments and the description thereof are
subject to mandatory automatic payroll withholding for employees of the
village:
      (1)   AFSCME: Dues deductions.
      (2)   Internal Revenue Service: Federal income tax and medicare.
      (3)   International Association of Firefighters: Dues deductions.
      (4)   International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 705: Dues deduction.
      (5)   International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 714: Dues deduction.
      (6)   Illinois Department of Revenue: State income tax.
      (7)   Illinois Fraternal Order of Police: Dues deduction.
      (8)   Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund: Municipal employee pension
contribution.
      (9)   Oak Brook Bank: Firefighter's pension contribution.
      (10)    Oak Brook Bank: Police pension contribution.
      (11)    State Disbursement Unit: Mandatory child support payments.
   (B)   The following benefits and payment are subject to voluntary automatic
payroll withholding for employees of the village:
      (1)   Allstate Insurance: Various optional insurance payments.
      (2)   CompBenefits: Dental insurance.
      (3)   Franklin Life Insurance: Optional life insurance.
      (4)   Great West Co.: Employee 457 plan contribution.
      (5)   NCPERS Group Life Insurance: Optional life insurance.
      (6)   PBA: Health, life and disability insurance.
      (7)   United Way: Charitable contribution.
(Ord. 06-46, passed 4-12-06)
§ 31.16 INDEMNIFICATION OF VILLAGE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   For the purposes of this section, ELECTED OR APPOINTED VILLAGE
OFFICIAL shall mean any present or former officer, member of a board,
commission or committee, whether or not compensated.
   (B)   If any claim is instituted against any village employee or elected or
appointed village official based on an injury allegedly arising out of an act
or omission occurring within the scope of the duties of a village official or
employment of a village employee, the village shall, with or without a
reservation of its rights:
      (1)   Appear and defend against the claim or action, through an attorney
appointed by the village or its insurance provider or in the absence, conflict
of interest or other disqualification of such attorney, by an attorney
appointed by the village employee or elected or appointed village official and
approved by the village;
      (2)   Indemnify the village employee or elected or appointed village
official for his or her court costs and attorney’s fees incurred in the defense
of such claim or action;
      (3)   Pay or indemnify the village employee or elected or appointed
village official, for a judgment based on such claim or action, excluding any
portion of the judgment representing an award of punitive or exemplary damages;
and
      (4)   Pay or indemnify the village employee or elected or appointed
village official for a compromise or settlement of such a claim of action,
provided that the settlement is approved by a majority of the members of the
Board of Trustees.
   (C)   The foregoing obligation to defend and/or indemnify shall not extend
to any of the following:
      (1)   Any matter in which the village employee or elected or appointed
village official is finally adjudged to be guilty of a criminal act. Whenever
any criminal proceeding is instituted against any village employee or elected
or appointed village official, the village’s obligation to defend and/or
indemnify the village employee or elected or appointed village official shall
be suspended pending the final outcome of the proceeding. Any defense costs or
indemnity that may have been paid to or on behalf of any village employee or
elected or appointed village official for any claim arising from any act or
omission that is determined to be a criminal act shall be reimbursed to the
village upon a final adjudication of guilt.
      (2)   Any action instituted by the village, including but not limited to
administrative investigatory or disciplinary proceedings, against any village
employee or elected or appointed village official;
      (3)   Any liability or judgment against a village employee or elected or
appointed village official which is payable to the village itself or where the
village official or employee either obtained personal benefit or financial gain
as a result of his or her wrongful conduct;
      (4)   Any liability, attorney’s fees or costs incurred as a result of an
investigation into the misconduct of the village employee or elected or
appointed village official instituted or approved by the village;
      (5)   Any liability, attorney’s fees or costs incurred as a result of the
village employee’s or appointed village official’s failure to reasonably
cooperate or participate in the defense of any claim, action, suit or
proceeding with any person, party or entity; or
      (6)   Any liability excluded by a written waiver from the village
employee or elected or appointed village official.
   (D)   The village may, but is not obligated to, fulfill all or a portion of
its obligation to defend and/or indemnify a village employee or an elected or
appointed village official through the purchase of insurance or participation
in any program of self insurance or of an intergovernmental insurance pooling
agreement.
(Ord. 9-13, passed 4-22-09)
§ 31.17 SECURITY PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT.
   The Police Department and/or related divisions and/or departments are/is
hereby authorized and directed to provide security personnel and equipment,
including but not limited to the necessary alarm systems for and on behalf of
the elected officials of the village in order to provide the necessary
protection for the persons and property of the respective elected officials.
(Ord. 10-21, passed 3-10-10)
§ 31.18 EMPLOYMENT HANDBOOK ADOPTED.
   The Employment Handbook, which sets forth certain guidelines, rules,
regulations and procedures pertaining to the employees of the village, is
hereby adopted by reference as if fully set forth herein. A copy of the
Employee Handbook is available for inspection during normal business hours in
the village offices.
(Ord. 12-42, passed 11-21-12; Am. Ord. 13-33, passed 11-20-13; Am. Ord. 19-20,
passed 6-19-19; Am. Ord. 21-22, passed 7-21-21)
ELECTED OFFICIALS
§ 31.20 VILLAGE PRESIDENT.
   (A)   Election; term. The Village President shall be elected for a term of
four years, and he or she shall be the President of the Board of Trustees, as
is provided by statute.
   (B)   Bond. Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the
President shall give a bond with sureties to be approved by the Board of
Trustees conditioned upon the faithful performance of his or her duties, in the
sum of $3,000.
   (C)   Duties generally. The President shall be the chief executive officer
of the village and he or she shall perform all such duties as may be required
of him or her by statute or by the provisions of this code and other or
ordinances of the village. He or she shall have supervision over all the
executive officers of the village, and over all the employees of the village.
   (D)   Inspection of books and records. The President may inspect all books
and records kept by any village officer or employee at any reasonable time.
   (E)   To designate duties and settle disputes. Whenever there is a question
as to the respective powers or duties of any appointed officer of the village,
this shall be settled by the President; and he or she shall have the power to
delegate to any such officer any duty which is to be performed when no specific
officer has been directed to perform that duty.
   (F)   President Pro Tem. During a temporary absence or disability of the
Village President the Board of Trustees shall elect one of its number to act as
President Pro Tem, who during the absence or disability of the President, shall
perform the duties pertaining to the office.
(`95 Code, § 31.20)
§ 31.21 VILLAGE CLERK.
   (A)   Election and term. The Village Clerk shall be elected and serve for a
four-year term and until his or her successor is elected and qualified, as
provided by statute.
   (B)   Filling of vacancy. In the event the office of Village Clerk shall
become vacant for any reason, the President and Board of Trustees shall appoint
a successor as provided by statute.
   (C)   Sealing and attesting contracts, licenses and the like. The Village
Clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the village and all licenses,
permits and such other documents as shall require this formality.
   (D)   Disposition of money collected. The Village Clerk shall turn over all
money received by him or her on behalf of the village to the Village Treasurer
promptly upon receipt of the same and with such money he or she shall give a
statement as to the source thereof.
   (E)   Accounts. The Village Clerk shall keep accounts showing all money
received by him or her and the source and disposition thereof and such other
accounts as may be required by statute or by the provisions of this code or
other ordinances of the village.
   (F)   Records. In addition to the record of ordinances and other records
which the Village Clerk is required by statute to keep, he or she shall keep
the following records:
      (1)   A register of all licenses and permits issued and the payments
thereon;
        (2)   A record showing all of the officers and regular employees of the
village; and
      (3)   Such other records as may be required by the Board of Trustees.
   (G)   Custody and use of village seal. The Village Clerk shall be the
custodian of the village seal and shall affix its impression on documents
whenever this is required.
   (H)   Custody of documents. The Village Clerk shall be the custodian of all
documents belonging to the village which are not assigned to the custody of
some other officer.
   (I)   Indices of documents and the like. The Village Clerk shall keep and
maintain proper indices to all documents and records kept by him or her, so
that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had.
   (J)   Additional duties. In addition to the duties provided in this section,
the Village Clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may be
required by statute or by the provisions of this code or other ordinances of
the village.
   (K)   Reporting responsibility. The Village Clerk shall report directly to
the Village President when performing duties assigned to him or her.
   (L)   Compensation. The Village Clerk shall receive, in equal installments,
an annual salary of $18,000, effective Mary 1, 2025. This rate of compensation
for the Village Clerk shall be paid in accordance with the ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5,
§§ 3.1-50-5 and 3.1-50-10.
   (M)   Village Collector. The Village Clerk may serve as the Village
Collector upon appointment by the Village President, by and with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees, and in accordance with statute or the
provisions of this code or other ordinances of the village.
(`95 Code, § 31.21) (Am. Ord. 01-09, passed 5-23-01; Am. Ord. 22-26, passed 7-
-22)
APPOINTIVE OFFICERS
§ 31.30 APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS; APPOINTMENTS; TERM OF OFFICE; ASSIGNMENT OF
DUTIES.
   (A)   Application of provisions. The provisions of this subchapter shall
apply alike to all officers and employees of the village, regardless of the
time of the creation of the office or position or the time of the appointment
of the officer or employee.
   (B)   Appointments. All officers other than elective officers shall be
appointed by the President and the Board of Trustees, as is provided by village
ordinance and/or statute; provided that all employees shall, in the absence of
any provisions to the contrary be appointed or selected by the Village
President.
   (C)   Term of office; vacancy.
      (1)   Every appointive officer of the village shall hold office until the
first day of May following his or her appointment or until his or her successor
is appointed and qualified, unless it is otherwise provided by this code or
other ordinances of the village. In case of a vacancy in any such place, it
shall be filled in the same manner in which appointments or selections are
made, in the absence of provision to the contrary.
      (2)   In the absence of a permanent appointment, the President, with the
advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, may appoint an acting officer for
a term not to exceed six months.
   (D)   Assignment of duties. The Board of Trustees may assign to any
appointive officer any duty which is not assigned by this code or other
ordinance to some specific officer.
(`95 Code, § 31.30) (Am. Ord. 85-07, passed 6-26-85; Am. Ord. 13-24, passed 9-
9-13)
§ 31.31 VILLAGE TREASURER.
   (A)   Creation of office; appointment and term. There is hereby created the
office of Village Treasurer, who shall be appointed by the President and Board
of Trustees as provided by statute. The Village Treasurer shall serve for one
year.
   (B)   Bond. The Village Treasurer shall give a bond, before entering upon
the duties of his or her office, in the sum required by the Board of Trustees,
but such amount shall not be less than that required by statute. This bond
shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of his or her duties by the
Treasurer, and shall be conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss by
reason of any neglect of duty or any act of the Treasurer.
   (C)   Duties generally. The Village Treasurer shall perform such duties as
may be prescribed for him or her by statute or by the provisions of this code
or other ordinances of the village. The Village Treasurer shall receive all
money paid into the village whether directly from the person paying the money
or from the hands of such other officer or employee as may receive it, and he
or she shall pay out money, only on vouchers or orders properly signed by the
President and Comptroller.
   (D)   Deposit of funds. The Village Treasurer shall deposit the village
funds in such depositories as may be selected from time to time as provided by
law. The Village Treasurer shall keep the deposit of the village money separate
and distinct from his or her own money, and shall not make private or personal
use of any village money.
   (E)   Records. The Treasurer shall keep records showing all money received
by him or her, showing the source from which it is received and the purpose for
which it is paid, and he or she shall keep records at all times showing the
financial status of the village.
   (F)   Accounting. The Treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be
required by statute, by the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the
village and he or she shall keep them in the manner required by the Board of
Trustees.
   (G)   Special assessments.
      (1)   Accounts generally. The Village Treasurer shall keep in suitable
books for that purpose an accurate and detailed account of each special
assessment levied for any improvement.
      (2)   Account showing assessments against village for public benefits.
The Village Treasurer shall keep a separate memorandum account showing the
amount assessed against the village for public benefits in each special
assessment in which public assessments have been assessed against the village.
Such account shall show the amount of each installment in each such assessment.
      (3)   Report of excess collected. When it shall appear from the books
kept as provided in division (G)(1) of this section that all costs and expenses
of any improvement which has been made by special assessment have been paid and
satisfied and that there has been a sum of money collected over and above the
entire cost of such improvement, the Village Treasurer shall report to the
President and Board of Trustees such fact and state in writing the amount of
such excess.
      (4)   Rebates. The Village Treasurer shall keep an account of all rebates
on special assessments ordered by the Board of Trustees, shall issue warrants
therefor to the respective parties entitled thereto and shall keep an account
of such warrants so issued. Whenever the full amount of any such rebate has
been paid out, the Village Treasurer shall report the fact to the President and
Board of Trustees.
(`95 Code, § 31.31) (Am. Ord. 88-8, passed 2-24-88)
§ 31.32 VILLAGE COMPTROLLER.
   (A)   Creation of office. There is hereby created the office of Village
Comptroller.
   (B)   Bond. Before entering upon the duties of his or her office the Village
Comptroller shall give bond in such sum as may be required by the Board of
Trustees with surety to be approved by the Board of Trustees conditioned for
the faithful discharge of his or her duties. Such bond shall be filed with the
Village Clerk.
   (C)   Statutory powers and duties. The Village Comptroller shall have the
powers conferred and perform the duties imposed upon comptrollers by statute
which are not included in the powers and duties specified in the following
divisions of this section.
   (D)   Additional responsibilities. In addition to those powers and duties
specified in §
31.32(C), the Village Comptroller shall perform those duties and
responsibilities specified in a job description which shall be established and
which may be changed from time-to-time by the Village Board.
   (E)   General supervision of municipal finances. The Village Comptroller
shall exercise a general supervision over all the officers of the village
charged in any manner with the receipt collection or disbursement of village
revenues, and the collection and return of all such revenue into the village
treasury, and generally, in subordination to the President and Board of
Trustees, shall exercise supervision over all such interests of the village, as
in any manner may concern or relate to the village finances, revenues and
property.
   (F)   Custody, and the like of deeds, contracts, bonds. The Village
Comptroller shall have charge, custody and control of all deeds, warrants,
vouchers, tax certificates and tax deeds, the custody and control of which is
not by statute or by the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the
village given to any other officer of the village.
   (G)   Settlements of accounts in which village is concerned. The Village
Comptroller shall, subject to the approval of the Board of Trustees, revise,
audit and settle all accounts in which the village is concerned, either as a
debtor or creditor, where provision for the settlement thereof is not otherwise
provided by law and the settlement of which is not specifically committed to
some other officer; provided, that no payment of any account so settled or
adjusted shall be made except by the order of the Board of Trustees after
approval by the Finance Committee of the Board of Trustees.
   (H)   Audit of accounts of Treasurer, Clerk and the like. The Village
Comptroller shall, annually, and more often if required by the Board of
Trustees, audit or cause to be audited, under authority of the Board of
Trustees, the accounts of the Village Treasurer, the Village Clerk, the
Superintendent of Public Works and all officers or other persons charged with
the collection and disbursement of village revenues. Immediately after such
auditing of such accounts, the Village Comptroller shall make a full report to
the President and Board of Trustees with such suggestions and recommendations
as he or she may deem advisable.
   (I)   Records showing appropriations, expenditures, receipts and the like.
The Village Comptroller shall keep in a clear and methodical manner a complete
set of books wherein shall be stated among other things the appropriations for
the fiscal year for each distinct object and branch of expenditure, all
unexpended balances and estimated receipts from every source of income and
revenue, the indebtedness of the village, whether bonded or otherwise, and
generally the financial condition of the village so far as practicable. Such
books shall be subject to examination by the President or any member of the
Board of Trustees.
   (J)   Annual report to budget estimate. The Village Comptroller shall each
year submit to the Chairperson of the Finance Committee of the Board of
Trustees a report of his or her estimates of monies necessary to defray the
expenses of the village during the current fiscal year. The Village Comptroller
shall in such report classify the different objects and branches of
expenditure, giving the amount required for each. For this purpose the
Comptroller is authorized to require of all officers a statement of the
condition and expenses of their respective offices, with any proposed
improvements and the probable expenses thereof, and of all contracts made and
unfinished and the amount of any and all unexpended appropriations for the
preceding year. In such report, the Village Comptroller shall give such other
information as the Comptroller or the Chairperson of the Finance Committee
shall deem necessary to a full understanding of the financial necessities of
the village for the current year.
   (K)   Annual submission and publication of statement of receipts and
expenditures. The Village Comptroller shall on or before May 1 in each year
make out and submit to the President and Board of Trustees and cause to be
published a full and complete statement of the receipts and expenditures of the
village during the previous fiscal year, showing on what account received and
expended.
   (L)   Monthly report of expenditures. At the end of each month, the Village
Comptroller shall transmit to the Board of Trustees a detailed record, as
approved by the Finance Committee of the Board of Trustees, showing the
aggregate of the expenditures during the month and classifying such
expenditures under the respective heads of assigned account numbers.
   (M)   Disposal of surplus property. Whenever the Comptroller determines that
personal property of the village is no longer necessary or useful, the
Comptroller shall provide for the disposal of the property by sale, auction,
trade-in or other method as the Comptroller shall determine is in the best
interest of the village. Before any final disposal of surplus property, the
Comptroller shall provide the Board of Trustees with an inventory of property
to be disposed of, with a brief explanation as to why each item is no longer
useful or necessary, and the manner in which the property is to be disposed of.
(`95 Code, § 31.32) (Am. Ord. 88-8, passed 2-24-88; Am. Ord. 01-09, passed 5-
23-01; Am. Ord. 02-02, passed 2-13-02)
§ 31.33 CORPORATION COUNSEL.
   (A)   Creation of office. There is hereby created the office of Corporation
Counsel, an executive office of the village. The Corporation Counsel shall be
appointed by the President and Board of Trustees.
   (B)   Suits and actions. The Corporation Counsel shall prosecute or defend
all suits or actions at law or equity to which the village may be a part, or in
which it may be interested, or which may be brought against or by any officer
of the village on behalf of the village or in the capacity of such person as an
officer of the village.
   (C)   Enforcement of judgments or decrees. It shall be the duty of the
Corporation Counsel to see to the full enforcement of all judgments or decrees
entered in favor of the village and of all similar interlocutory orders.
   (D)   Advice and opinions. The Corporation Counsel shall be the legal
advisor of the village and shall render advice on all legal questions affecting
it, whenever requested to do so by any village official. Upon request by the
President of the Board of Trustees, he or she shall reduce any such opinion to
writing.
   (E)   Compensation. The Corporation Counsel shall receive, in equal monthly
installments, such compensation as may be fixed by the Board of Trustees for
the performance of his or her ordinary duties. The Corporation Counsel shall
receive additional compensation, as fixed by the Board of Trustees, for his or
her services pertaining to special assessments and appearances in court on
behalf of the village.
   (F)   Village Attorney. The President, with the consent of the Board of
Trustees may appoint a Village Attorney(s) to assist the Corporation Counsel in
the performance of his duties. Such Village Attorney shall work at the
direction and assist the Corporation Counsel in the performance of his pursuit
of village legal matters.
   (G)   Special counsel. The Corporation Counsel may from time to time retain
an attorney to represent or advise the village on legal matters or to assist
the Corporation Counsel.
   (H)   Staff attorney. The Corporation Counsel may retain a staff attorney,
who will be an at will employee of the village, compensated at the rate of
$5,000 per month. The staff attorney must be an attorney licensed to practice
law in the State of Illinois for at least ten years, in good standing. The
staff attorney shall perform duties as assigned and supervised by the
Corporation Counsel.
   (I)   Residency. Any professional employee of the village who is an attorney
licensed to practice law in the State of Illinois shall not be required to be a
resident of the Village of Bellwood.
(`95 Code, § 31.33) (Am. Ord. 01-46, passed 12-20-01; Am. Ord. 6-99, passed 10-
25-06)
§ 31.34 PROSECUTING ATTORNEY.
   (A)   Creation of office; appointment. There is hereby created the office of
Prosecuting Attorney. The Prosecuting Attorney shall be appointed by the
President and Board of Trustees of the village.
   (B)   Compensation. The compensation of the Prosecuting Attorney shall be
fixed at the time of his or her appointment.
   (C)   Bond. The bond of the Prosecuting Attorney shall be fixed by the Board
of Trustees at the time of his or her appointment.
   (D)   Duties. The Prosecuting Attorney shall prosecute all violations of the
provisions of this code and other ordinances of the village and appeals thereof
to which the village may be a party or in which it may be interested. All
appeals shall be under the direction and supervision of the Village Attorney.
The Prosecuting Attorney shall also perform such other and further legal
services as the Board of Trustees may direct or that the Village Attorney may
request.
   (E)   Reports on work done. The President and Board of Trustees may request
monthly reports or interim reports on work done by the office of Prosecuting
Attorney.
(`95 Code, § 31.34) (Ord. 61-14, passed - -)
§ 31.35 POLICE MAGISTRATE.
   (A)   Term of office. The Police Magistrate shall hold his or her office for
the term of four years and until his or her successor is elected and qualified,
as provided by law.
   (B)   Bond. Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the Police
Magistrate shall execute a bond in the sum of $2,500 to the village.
   (C)   Duties. The Police Magistrate shall perform the duties imposed upon
him or her by the laws of the state and the ordinances of the village.
   (D)   Disposition of fines and costs. All fines and costs collected by the
Police Magistrate for violations of the provisions of this code and other
ordinances of the village shall be turned over to the Village Comptroller.
   (E)   Court clerk. The Police Magistrate shall make whatever provisions he
or she deems desirable to provide for a court clerk.
   (F)   When docket to be open for inspection. The docket of the Police
Magistrate shall be open to inspection by the police during all business hours
of the day.
(`95 Code, § 31.35) (Ord. 52-13, passed - -; Am. Ord. 61-2, passed - -)
§ 31.36 DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS.
   (A)   Creation of office; appointment. There is hereby created the office of
Director of Public Works, an executive office of the village. The Director of
Public Works shall be appointed by the President by and with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees.
   (B)   Compensation. The compensation of the Director of Public Works shall
be fixed at the time of his or her appointment.
   (C)   Supervision of officers and employees of Department of Public Works.
All employees assigned to the Department of Public Works shall perform their
duties subject to the orders and under the supervision of the Director of
Public Works.
   (D)   Powers and duties. The Director of Public Works shall have charge and
care of the following:
      (1)   Functioning, maintenance and repair of the village water works and
water distribution systems;
      (2)   Functioning, maintenance and repair of all public streets, alleys
and driveways in the village and wit the keeping of the same clean;
      (3)   Functioning, maintenance and repair of all gutters and drains and
with the keeping of the same clean and free from defects;
      (4)   Functioning, maintenance and repair of sanitary and storm sewer
systems of the village and shall see to it that the same are kept in good
repair and free from defects; and
      (5)   Functioning, maintenance and repair of the lighting of the public
streets and alleys and shall keep the lighting system in efficient operation
and good repair.
   (E)   Reports on work done. The Village President or Comptroller may request
monthly reports or interim reports on work done by the office of the Director
of Public Works; they shall also receive recommendations for rulings, orders or
ordinances respecting the water quality and public health of the residents of
the village whenever he or she is requested to do so, or whenever he or she
deems it advisable.
   (F)   Additional duties. The Director of Public Works shall perform such
duties and functions, in addition to those delineated in this section, as may
be required by statute or the provisions of this code or other ordinances of
the village.
(`95 Code, § 31.36) (Am. Ord. 05-29, passed 9-14-05; Am. Ord. 11-38, passed 8-
17-11)
§ 31.37 HEALTH OFFICER.
   (A)   Creation; appointment. There is hereby created the office of Health
Officer, an executive office of the village. The Health Officer shall be
appointed by the President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees.
   (B)   Enforcement of code provisions, and the like as to public health. The
Health Officer shall enforce all provisions of this code and other ordinances
of the village relative to the protection of public health.
   (C)   Inspection of foodstuffs, and the like. The Health Officer shall make
such inspections of foodstuffs and the premises used for storing or selling of
provisions as may be provided by the provisions of this code or other
ordinances of the village.
   (D)   Enforcement of rules of Board of Health; attendance at meetings. The
Health Officer shall enforce all the rules and orders of the Board of Health
and shall attend the meetings of the Board of Health when requested to do so by
the presiding officer.
   (E)   Reports and recommendations. The Health Officer shall make such
reports to the Board of Trustees as may be required. The Health Officer shall
also make recommendations for rulings, orders or ordinances respecting the
public health whenever he or she is requested to do so, or whenever he or she
deems it advisable or necessary.
   (F)   Additional duties. The Health Officer shall perform such duties and
functions, in addition to those delineated in this section, as may be required
by statute or the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the village.
(`95 Code, § 31.37)
§ 31.38 VILLAGE SANITARIAN.
   (A)   Position created. The position of Village Sanitarian is hereby
created. The Village Sanitarian shall be appointed by the President and Board
of Trustees.
   (B)   Powers and duties. The Village Sanitarian is charged with the duty of
enforcing all provisions of this code and state statute pertaining to public
health. In accomplishing his or her duties, he or she shall have the power to
inspect premises at reasonable hours, to take samples of foodstuffs and
material for testing, and to issue such orders as may be necessary for, and
conducive to, the public health.
(`95 Code, § 31.38) (Ord. 78-1, passed 1-11-78)
§ 31.39 ASSISTANT HEALTH OFFICER.
   (A)   Creation of office; appointment. There is hereby created the office of
Assistant Health Officer, an executive office of the village. The Assistant
Health Officer shall be appointed by the President, by and with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees.
   (B)   Compensation. The compensation for the Assistant Health Officer shall
be made by the President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
   (C)   Assistant to Health Officer. The Assistant Health Officer shall assist
the Health Officer in the enforcement of all provisions of this code and other
ordinances of the village relative to the protection of public health. The
Assistant Health Officer shall also assist the Health Officer in making
inspections of foodstuffs and of the premises used for storage or selling of
provisions, as referred to in §
31.37(C). He or she shall assist the Health Officer in the inspection of all
premises used as food establishments.
   (D)   Enforcement of rules of Board of Health; attendance at meetings. The
Assistant Health Officer shall enforce all the rules and orders of the Board of
Health and shall attend the meetings of the Board when requested to do so by
the presiding officer.
   (E)   Reports and recommendations. The Assistant Health Officer shall make
such reports to the Board of Trustees as may be required. The Assistant Health
Officer shall also make recommendations for rulings, orders or ordinances
respecting the public health whenever he or she is requested to do so or
whenever he or she deems it advisable or necessary.
(`95 Code, § 31.39)
§ 31.40 BUILDING COMMISSIONER.
   (A)   Creation of position; appointment. There is hereby created the
position of Building Commissioner, who shall be appointed by the President and
Board of Trustees.
   (B)   Enforcement of code provisions, and the like, as to buildings or
zoning. The Building Commissioner shall see to the enforcement of all
provisions of this code and other ordinances of the city relating to buildings
or zoning.
   (C)   Inspection of buildings, and the like under construction or
alteration. The Building Commissioner shall inspect all buildings or structures
being constructed or altered as frequently as may be necessary to insure
compliance with the provisions of this code and other ordinances of the
village.
   (D)   Right of entry. The Building Commissioner may, at any reasonable hour,
make or cause to be made an entry into any building or premises where the work
of altering, repairing or constructing of any building or structure is going
on, for the purpose of making inspections.
   (E)   Stop-work order when construction of building violates construction
ordinances, and the like.  
      (1)   The Building Commissioner may order all work stopped on
construction, alteration or repair of buildings in the village when such work
is being done in violation of any provision of this code or any other ordinance
of the village relating thereto or in violation of
Chapter 156 Zoning. Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such all
order except on the written permission of the Building Commissioner. However,
if the stop order is an oral one, it shall be followed by a written stop order
within an hour. Such stop order may be served by any police officer.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful for any person to continue work in violation
of a stop order of the Building Commissioner given under the provisions of the
division (E)(1) of this section.
(`95 Code, § 31.40)

(`95 Code, § 31.42) (Am. Ord. 85-04, passed 6-12-85)
§ 31.43 VILLAGE MARSHAL AND DEPUTY MARSHALS.
   (A)   Village Marshals.
      (1)   Offices of Village Marshals established; appointments. There is
hereby established the offices of Village Marshals who shall be appointed by
the President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees in such
number as shall be determined from to time by the corporate authorities.
      (2)   Term of office; removal; compensation.
         (a)   The Village Marshals shall each serve at the discretion of the
President and Board of Trustees and may be removed from office at the will of
the President and Board of Trustees.
         (b)   Each Village Marshal shall receive such hourly compensation for
services as determined by the corporate authorities. Village Marshals shall
maintain their permanent residences in the village.
      (3)   Duties and responsibilities. The Village Marshals shall not be
considered to be members of the regular police force. Their duties and
responsibilities shall be as fully set forth by the Chief of Police regarding
the enforcement of all village ordinances and codes pertaining to local
building, health, licensing, animal, non-moving vehicles and any other
ordinances or codes specifically assigned to the Village Marshals in the area
of public safety. The Village Marshals shall also be known as the Public Safety
Specialists or Inspectors.
      (4)   Carrying firearms. The Village Marshals are authorized to carry
firearms while on duty subject to such licensing and training as determined by
the statutes of the state of Illinois and the directives of the Chief of
Police.
   (B)   Deputy Marshals.
      (1)   Office of Deputy Marshal established; appointment. There is hereby
established the office of Deputy Marshal. Deputy Marshals shall be appointed by
the President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees in such
number as the corporate authorities shall from time to time deem necessary.
Deputy Marshals shall maintain their permanent residence in the village.
      (2)   Terms of office; removal from office; compensation.
         (a)   The Deputy Marshals shall serve at the discretion of the
President and Board of Trustees and may be removed from office at the will of
the President and Board of Trustees.
         (b)   The Deputy Marshals shall receive such hourly compensation for
their services as determined by the corporate authorities. In the event the
Deputy Marshals elect union representation, the collective bargaining agreement
shall be consulted.
      (3)   Supervision by Chief of Police. The Deputy Marshals shall not be
considered members of the Police Department and shall not function on a full-
time basis. Identification symbols of the Deputy Marshals shall be different
and distinct from those used by the members of Police Department. The Deputy
Marshals shall at all times during the performance of their duties be subject
to the direction and control of the Chief of Police in support of Police
Community Relations and other civilian level support services.
      (4)   Duties and responsibilities. Deputy Marshals shall perform such
duties as determined by the Chief of Police.
      (5)   Carrying firearms. Deputy Marshals shall not carry firearms except
with the special permission of and when issued by the Chief of Police, and when
in uniform and while in the performance of their duties. The carrying of
firearms by Deputy Marshals shall be subject to such licensing and training as
determined by the statutes of the state of Illinois and by the directives of
the Chief of Police.
(`95 Code, § 31.43) (Ord. 91-11, passed 7-10-91)
§ 31.44 ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT SPECIALIST.
   (A)   Position created. There is hereby created the position of Economic
Development Specialist. The person to fill this position shall be hired by the
Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
   (B)   Salary. The salary attached to the position of Economic Development
Specialist shall be as set by the President and Board of Trustees.
   (C)   Term. The Economic Development Specialist shall serve at will.
   (D)   Duties. The Economic Development Specialist shall report directly to
the Village Clerk and shall be responsible for: reviewing the commercial and
industrial development of the village; for advising the Village Clerk and
Village President of recommendations to maintain and improve the conditions
with the assistance of such grants, tax incentives and other economic
development procedures as approved by the Village President and Board of
Trustees; and for performing such other duties as may be assigned by the
Village Clerk or Village President.
(`95 Code, § 31.44) (Ord. 89-10, passed 6-14-89)
§ 31.45 BUDGET OFFICER.
   (A)   Created. There is created the office of Budget Officer/Director of
Finance for the Village of Bellwood, pursuant to the Illinois Municipal Code,
ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 8-2-9.1.
   (B)   Appointment. The Budget Officer/Director of Finance shall be appointed
by the Village President with a two-third majority vote of those members of the
corporate authority then holding office.
   (C)   Duties. The duties of the Budget Officer/Director of Finance shall be
those set forth in the Illinois Municipal Code, ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 8-2-9.2.
   (D)   Compensation. The Budget Officer/Director of Finance shall receive as
compensation an amount set by ordinance passed by the corporate authority.
(Am. Ord. 96-19, passed 7-17-96; Am. Ord. 12-33, passed 9-19-12)

Chief of Staff, an executive office of the village.
   (B)   Appointment. The Assistant to the President/Chief of Staff shall be
appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees.
   (C)   Duties. The duties of the Assistant to the President/Chief of Staff
shall be those prescribed by the President.

§ 31.47 ASSISTANT SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS.
   (A)   Creation of office; appointment. There is hereby created the office of
Assistant Superintendent of Public Works, an executive office of the village.
The Assistant Superintendent(s) shall be appointed by the President by and with
the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The village may appoint up to
two Assistants, depending on the needs of the community and department, to
assist and carry out the directives and instructions of the Director of Public
Works.
   (B)   Compensation. The compensation of the Assistant Superintendent of
Public Works shall be fixed at the time of his or her appointment.
   (C)   Duties. The Assistant Superintendent(s) of Public Works shall report
directly to the Director of Public Works and be responsible for the supervision
of all employees assigned to the Department of Public Works all of whom shall
perform their duties subject to the orders and under the supervision of the
Director of Public Works.

§ 31.50 DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SAFETY.
   (A)   Creation. There shall be and is hereby created the office of Director
of Public Safety, an administrative office within the village.
   (B)   Appointment. The Director of Public Safety shall be appointed by the
President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
   (C)   Supervision of the Public Safety Group. The Director of Public Safety
shall supervise all aspects of the Public Safety Group which shall include but
not be limited to the business aspects as assigned to the Department in the
annual budget.
   (D)   Duties. The Director of Public Safety shall oversee the activities and
administrative operations of the personnel and contracts assigned to the Public
Safety Group. The respective chiefs of each department shall report directly to
the Director of Public Safety. The Director of Public Safety shall coordinate
the operations of the Bellwood Police Department, Bellwood Fire Department and
the Bellwood Office of Emergency Management. This oversight shall include but
not be limited to responsibility over budget, operations, discipline,
personnel, appointments and policy issues.
(Ord. 10-96, passed 10-13-10)
§ 31.51 VILLAGE COLLECTOR.
   (A)   Creation of office. The position of Village Collector is hereby
created, effective May 1, 2025.
   (B)   Appointment and term. The Village Collector shall be appointed by the
President, by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, in
accordance with ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-30-5. The Village Collector shall
serve for a term of one year.
   (C)   Duties. The Village Collector, under the supervision of the Village
President, shall perform the required statutory duties along with any other
duties assigned from time-to-time by the Village President.
   (D)   Additional duties. In addition to the duties provided in this section,
the Village Collector shall perform such other duties and functions as may be
required by statute or by the provisions of this code or other ordinances of
the village.
   (E)   Reporting responsibility. The Village Collector shall report directly
to the Village President.
(Ord. 22-26, passed 7- -22)
PUBLIC SERVICE EMPLOYMENT AND INTERNSHIP PROGRAM
§ 31.60 ESTABLISHMENT OF A PUBLIC SERVICE EMPLOYMENT PROGRAM.
   There is established a Public Service Employment Program, which will provide
temporary employment in the field of human betterment and community
improvement. The Public Services Employment Program is temporary part-time
employment assignment lasting 25 to 52 weeks depending on the circumstances of
the assignment. All hires (public service assistants) shall be subject to a 90-
day probationary period. A component of the program will be job training and
permanent employment assistance.
(Ord. 02-34, passed 9-25-02)
§ 31.61 DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SERVICE EMPLOYMENT.
   (A)   The Village Board, upon recommendation of the President, may appoint a
Director of Public Service Employment, to direct a Public Service Employment
Program. The Director will report to the Village President's office, under whom
the Public Service Employment Program is directed.
   (B)   The Director shall:
      (1)   Serve as and perform all functions of the Director of Public
Service Employment, as set forth in the position job description; and
      (2)   Organize and manage the Public Services Employment Program; and
      (3)   Serve as the head of the community property maintenance inspections
of the village; and
      (4)   Submit to the Village President plans and programs relating to the
Public Services Employment Program; and
      (5)   Prescribe such rules and regulations as approved by the Village
President to manage the conduct of the Public Services Employment Program; and
      (6)   Be responsible for the proper maintenance of all village property
and equipment used in his or her department; and
      (7)   Keep informed as to the latest practices for such a program, and
inaugurate, with the approval of the Village President, such new practices as
appear to be a benefit to the village and the public.
(Ord. 02-34, passed 9-25-02)
§ 31.62 ESTABLISHMENT OF A PUBLIC SERVICES INTERN PROGRAM.
   There is established a Public Services Intern Program to provide experience
in municipal government and community organizations for high school, college,
and post-graduate students. The Public Services Intern Program is established
to provide meaningful curriculum related experience in a professional working
environment. These internships will be unpaid unless so otherwise designated.
The availability of such internships will be dependent upon organizational
needs as determined by the Village President.
(Ord. 02-34, passed 9-25-02)
§ 31.63 SUPERVISION OF THE PUBLIC SERVICES INTERN PROGRAM.
   The supervision of the Public Services Intern Program will be the
responsibility of the Village Clerk's office in consultation with the office of
the Village President.
(Ord. 02-34, passed 9-25-02)
§ 31.64 PROGRAM OPPORTUNITIES.
   The Public Services Intern Program positions will be developed in the areas
of Building, Hearing Adjudication, Legal, Finance, Information Technology,
Village President's office, Village Clerk's office, Human Resources,
Engineering, Planning and Economic Development, Marketing, Police, Fire and
Public Works. To enhance such internship opportunities partnerships will be
sought with educational institutions, as well as business and industry. The
Village Clerk's office shall promulgate such rules and regulations as may be
necessary to administer the Public Services Intern Program.
(Ord. 02-34, passed 9-25-02)

CODE ENFORCEMENT BOARD OF APPEALS
§ 32.001 ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT; TERM.
   (A)   There is hereby established a “Code Enforcement Board of Appeals.” The
“Board” when used in this section shall be construed to mean the “Code
Enforcement Board of Appeals.” The Board shall consist of five members to be
appointed by the Village President and with the consent of the Village Board.
The administrative functions of the Board shall be designated by the Village
President as part of the day to day operations of the village. The five members
of the Board shall not be employees of the village. At least three members of
the Board shall be professionally involved in at least one of the fields or
trades involving engineering, architectural services, building construction or
such related professional background as approved by the Board of Trustees of
the village provided that (1) there shall not be more than any one member of
the Board selected from the same profession or business; (2) at least two of
the members of the Board must be residents of the village; (3) at least one of
the members of the Board must be skilled in real estate and property
management. The Village President in announcing his or her appointments may
designate one member to act as Chair and one member to act as Vice-Chair for a
period of one year and thereafter annually designate a member to serve as Chair
and Vice-Chair. A member of the village staff shall serve as a reporting
secretary for the hearings and meetings conducted by the Board of Appeals. Two
members shall be appointed to an initial one-year term and three members shall
be appointed for a term of two years and will hold office until a successor has
been appointed. Thereafter, all members shall be appointed for a term of two
years and will hold office until a successor has been appointed. Vacancies on
the Board shall be filled in the same manner that original appointments are and
shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose place has become
vacant.
(Ord. 02-47, passed 11-13-02)
§ 32.002 NOTICE OF MEETING.
   The Board shall meet upon notice issued by the Village Clerk, or by his or
her assistant, or by the Chair, within 20 days of the filing of an appeal or at
stated periodic meetings if warranted by the volume of work. All meetings and
hearings conducted by said Board shall be open to the public. Any person may
appear and testify at a hearing either in person or by duly authorized agent or
attorney.
(Ord. 02-47, passed 11-13-02)
§ 32.003 BUILDING COMMISSIONER/FIRE CHIEF/FIRE INSPECTOR'S DECISIONS;
GRIEVANCE; APPEAL.
   In the event that any person, firm or corporation who is either the legal or
equitable owner of any property or the duly authorized agent of any legal or
equitable owner of any property, the architect, engineer, contractor or builder
in charge of and responsible for the performance of any work or operation,
disagrees with or is aggrieved by an order or decision of the Building
Commissioner or Fire Chief or Fire Inspector in all cases which relate to any
matter or thing pertaining to the issuance of permits or inspection violations
which are not specifically provided for in the building codes, fire codes, and
the like, or which relates to any matter or thing concerning permits or
inspections which, by the provisions of the code, the Building Commissioner or
Fire Chief or Fire Inspector may either approve or disapprove or when there are
practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the
ordinance, so that the spirit of this subchapter pertaining to the issuance of
permits shall be observed and public safety secured and substantial justice
done, such person, firm, or corporation shall have the right to appeal such
order or decision of the Building Commissioner, Fire Chief, or Fire Inspector
pertaining to such actions as enumerated above to the Board.
(Ord. 02-47, passed 11-13-02)
§ 32.004 BOARD TO HAVE JURISDICTION OVER BUILDING COMMISSIONER/FIRE CHIEF/FIRE
INSPECTOR DECISIONS.
   The Code Enforcement Board of Appeals shall have the powers and authority to
review, reverse and affirm, in whole or in part, or may modify, the order,
requirement, decision, or determinations of the Building Commissioner/Fire
Chief/Fire Inspector which has been presented for review. The Chairperson, or
in his or her absence, the acting chairperson, may administer and compel the
attendance of witnesses. The Board shall keep minutes of its proceedings
showing the vote of each member upon each question, or, if absent or failing to
vote, indicating such fact, and shall also keep records of its hearings and
other official actions. A court reporter shall be present for all proceedings
but such record of hearings will not be transcribed by the court reporter
unless requested by the parties or any party interested in the hearing. The
cost of the transcription shall be borne by the person requesting it. A copy of
every rule or regulation, and every order, requirement, decision, or
determination of the Board shall be kept on file in the office of the Village
Clerk and shall be a public record. All orders, decisions, or determinations of
the Board which reverse or modify the decision of the Building Commissioner/
Fire Chief/ Fire Inspector shall contain a statement to the effect that in the
opinion of the said Board that the work proposed shall not endanger life,
health, or safety of the building occupants or area residents. A copy of all
orders, decisions or determinations of the Board shall be mailed to the
applicant and those interested parties.
(Ord. 02-47, passed 11-13-02)
§ 32.005 POSTPONED HEARING; ADJOURNED MEETING.
   When three or more members are not present at the first hearing date to
consider a specific appeal, either the appellant, the village official or their
representatives may request a postponement of the hearing to a date not greater
than ten from the date of the originally scheduled hearing. In the event that
only one member is available at the adjourned hearing, that member may conduct
a hearing and issue a decision to affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the
village official. Said member shall note in the written decision that manner
and confirmation of the notice of the adjourned meeting date being provided to
the other member of the Board.
(Ord. 02-47, passed 11-13-02)
§ 32.006 LIMITATION OF BOARD JURISDICTION.
   All decisions of the Board shall apply only to the individual case being
reviewed and shall not be construed as a precedent for similar work or as a
change in the building code. The Board shall not have jurisdiction over matters
pertaining to materials methods or systems of construction, or arrangements of
materials, not permitted by the village code, or varying from the performance
of the village code. The Board shall affirm, modify or reverse the decision of
the village official by a majority vote in concurrence by those members in
attendance.
(Ord. 02-47, passed 11-13-02)
§ 32.007 APPEAL PROCEDURE.
   (A)   The person, firm or corporation who is desiring a review of an order
or decision of the Building Commissioner/ Fire Chief/Fire Inspector pertaining
to permits shall file with the Village Comptroller's office a written petition,
on a form to be provided, within seven days of the particular order or decision
to be reviewed has been issued by the village official requesting that the
particular order or decision be reviewed by the Board. The person, firm,
corporation, requesting such review shall also file with the Village
Comptroller's office any and all pertinent data or information that he or she
or it may care to present to the Board for its consideration, together with a
filing fee payable to the village in the amounts as follows:
      (1)   One hundred dollars for single-family dwellings as well as
miscellaneous buildings and structures related to the single-family dwelling;
      (2)   One hundred fifty dollars for buildings containing two to four
dwelling units;
      (3)   Two hundred and fifty dollars for all other occupancies.
   (B)   Upon the filing of a petition to review any decision or order of the
village official any and all work or operations which will or may be directly
or indirectly affected by any such decision or order shall cease and no such
work or operations shall be commenced until and after a decision or decisions
have been rendered by the Board; and any and all terms and provisions of any
such decision or decisions of the Board shall have been fully complied with.
All decisions and findings of the Board, on an appeal, after a hearing, shall,
in instances, be a final administrative determination and shall be subject to
review by a court of law as maybe provided.
(Ord. 02-47, passed 11-13-02)
BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS
§ 32.020 CREATION; DUTIES.
   There is hereby created a Board of Local Improvements to do and to perform
all the duties and functions incumbent upon and to be exercised by a Board of
Local Improvements, as provided in and by an act of the general assembly of the
state, entitled “An Act Concerning Local Improvements,” approved June 14, 1897,
and amendments thereof and supplements thereto.
(`95 Code, § 32.20) (Ord. 51-20, passed - - )
§ 32.021 COMPOSITION; TERMS.
   The Board of Local Improvements shall be composed of the Board of Trustees
and the Village President. The Village President shall be chairperson of the
Board of Local Improvements, and the Village Clerk shall be Secretary of the
Board of Local Improvements.
(`95 Code, § 32.21) (Ord. 51-20, passed - - )
§ 32.022 COMPENSATION.

Secretary of the Board of Local Improvements, shall receive as compensation the
amount of $350 per month.
