AUCTIONS AND AUCTIONEERS
§ 117.001 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   License required. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to engage in the business of an auctioneer, or to hold auctions in
the village, without having first obtained a license therefor.
   (B)   Fee. The annual fee for engaging in the business of an auctioneer
shall be $25 and the fee for holding a single auction shall be $10 for one who
does not have an annual license.
(`95 Code, § 117.001) (Ord. 54-4, passed - - ) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.002 CONDUCT OF AUCTIONS.
   All auctions shall be conducted in an orderly manner. It shall be unlawful
to create or permit any disturbance or disorderly conduct at any auction.
(`95 Code, § 117.002) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.003 FRAUDULENT STATEMENTS CONCERNING GOODS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person selling goods at auction to make any
fraudulent or untrue statements concerning the goods or articles sold.
(`95 Code, § 117.003) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.004 ARTICLES TO BE OFFERED FOR INSPECTION.
   Every article offered for sale at a public auction shall be open to the
inspection of any person wishing to purchase it at some time before or during
the bidding.
(`95 Code, § 117.004)
BARBERSHOPS, BEAUTY SHOPS, SALONS AND SPAS
§ 117.015 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   License required. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or
operate a barbershop in the village without having first obtained a license
therefor.
   (B)   Application. Application for the license required in division (A) of
this section shall be made in writing to the Village Clerk and shall state
thereon the number of chairs to be used in the establishment.
   (C)   Fee. The annual fee for the license required by division (A) of this
section shall be $10 for each chair used and no license shall be issued except
upon the payment of the fee.
   (D)   Hours of operation. No barbershop, beauty shop, salon or spa shall be
operated or open to the public any day of the week before 7:30 a.m. or after
10:00 p.m.
   (E)   Revocation. Any license issued pursuant to this subchapter may be
revoked for violation of this subchapter.
(`95 Code, § 117.015) (Ord. 54-4, passed - - ; Am. Ord. 14-38, passed 7-16-14)
Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.016 SANITARY STANDARDS.
   (A)   Premises to be kept clean and sanitary; persons with contagious
disease not to be employed. Premises used for a barbershop shall be kept in a
clean and sanitary condition, and it shall be unlawful to permit waste material
of any kind to accumulate therein. It shall be unlawful to employ in such
establishments any person afflicted with a venereal or contagious disease.
   (B)   Sterilization of implements. It shall be unlawful to use in any
establishment used as a barber shop any implements or tools upon any person
after the same have been used upon a person afflicted with any skin disease or
any scalp disease without first sterilizing the implement or tool. It shall be
unlawful to use any towel on any customer after the same has been used before
without having such towel sterilized and cleaned prior to such second usage.
(`95 Code, § 117.016) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.017 INSPECTION OF PREMISES.
   It shall be the duty of the Health Officer or some other person designated
by the Village President and Board of Trustees to inspect every establishment
licensed under this subchapter as often as necessary to insure compliance with
this subchapter and all other provisions of this code and other ordinances of
the village relative thereto.
(`95 Code, § 117.017)
COIN-OPERATED LAUNDRIES AND DRY CLEANERS
§ 117.025 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   Any person, firm or corporation operating an automatic coin-operated dry
cleaning establishment shall first obtain a business license from the village
by making application for same with the Village Clerk.
(`95 Code, § 117.025) (Ord. 62-4, passed - - ) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.026 COMPLIANCE WITH ELECTRICAL CODE.
   No license to operate a coin-operated laundry or dry cleaning establishment
shall be granted unless the installation of the machines complies with the
electrical code of the village.
(`95 Code, § 117.026)
§ 117.027 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No automatic coin-operated laundry or dry cleaners shall remain open between
the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m.
(`95 Code, § 117.027) (Ord. 60-17, passed - - ) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.028 ATTENDANTS REQUIRED.
   All automatic coin-operated dry cleaners obtaining a permit to establish
such business in the village shall have an attendant or employee present on the
premises at all times during which the automatic coin-operated dry cleaning
establishment is open to the public for business. All attendants or employees
shall be over 18 years of age.
(`95 Code, § 117.028)
DAY NURSERIES
§ 117.040 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DAY NURSERY. Any child care facility receiving one or more children for care
during part or all of a day between 6:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. and includes
facilities commonly called CHILD CARE CENTERS, DAY NURSERIES, NURSERY SCHOOLS,
KINDERGARTENS and PLAY GROUPS, with or without stated educational purposes. DAY
NURSERY does not include bona fide kindergartens or nursery schools operating
under the auspices of established public or private boards of education; bona
fide kindergartens or nursery schools approved by the Superintendent of Public
Instruction or the schools districts in which such kindergartens or nursery
schools are located; or those facilities operated in connection with a shopping
center or shopping service where transient children are received while parents
are shopping on the premises.
(`95 Code, § 117.040)
§ 117.041 PERMIT PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Permit required. Every person desiring to operate a day nursery in the
village shall obtain a permit therefor before commencing operation.
   (B)   Application. Every person desiring a permit to operate a day nursery
shall make application therefor to the Village Clerk on forms furnished by him
or her. The application shall contain such information as may be required by
the Village Clerk.
   (C)   Investigations. Upon receipt of an application for a permit required
by division (A) of this section, the Village Clerk shall refer it to the Health
Officer for investigation. The Health Officer shall inspect the premises
wherein the day nursery is proposed as to the following conditions:
      (1)   The operation and conduct of the facility and the responsibility it
assumes for child care.
      (2)   The character, suitability and qualifications of the applicant and
other persons directly responsible for the care and welfare of children served.
      (3)   The general financial ability and competence of the applicant to
provide necessary care for children and to maintain prescribed standards.
      (4)   The adequacy of the number of individuals required to insure
adequate supervision and care of the children.
      (5)   The appropriateness, safety, cleanliness and general adequacy of
the premises, including maintenance of adequate fire prevention and health
standards in conformance to state laws.
      (6)   Provisions for food, clothing, educational opportunities, programs,
equipment and individual supplies to assure the healthy physical, mental and
spiritual development of the children served.
      (7)   Discipline of the children.
   (D)   Issuance; appeal to Board.
      (1)   If, after investigation, the Health Officer recommends the issuance
of the permit, the Village Clerk shall issue such permit, which shall be valid
for the village license year.
      (2)   Any person aggrieved by the failure of the Health Officer to
approve the issuance of a day nursery permit may appeal to the Board of
Trustees, whose decision shall be final.
   (E)   Revocation. Any permit issued under the terms of this subchapter may
be revoked for the following reasons:
      (1)   Consistent failure to maintain health standards prescribed.
      (2)   Violation of the terms of the permit.
      (3)   Furnishing or making false or misleading information in the
application.
(`95 Code, § 117.041) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.042 STANDARDS AND INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   The Health Officer of the village shall prescribe rules and
regulations pertaining to the operation and standards of day nurseries.
   (B)   The Health Officer and the Fire Chief shall make periodic inspections
of all premises used as day nurseries and shall issue such orders as they deem
necessary to maintain health standards and fire protection.
(`95 Code, § 117.042)
DRY CLEANERS
§ 117.055 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DRY CLEANING. The process of cleaning fabric by immersion and agitation, or
by immersion only, in volatile solvents (including but not by way of
limitation, solvents of petroleum distillate type, the coal tar distillate type
and the chlorinated hydro- carbon type) and processes incidental thereto
(including, but without limitation, spotting, cleaning, wet cleaning and
finishing.)
   DRY CLEANING ESTABLISHMENT. Any structure, store, building or other place
where the service of dry cleaning, wet cleaning as a process incidental to dry
cleaning, dyeing, spotting or finishing any fabric is rendered for hire, or is
sold, resold or offered for sale or resale.
   FABRIC. Any article of wearing apparel, household furnishing, rugs,
textiles, fur and leather.
   FINISHING. The process of pressing or reshaping any fabric, which is
designed to restore as nearly as possible the shape, dimensions and contour of
its fabric.
   SPOTTING. The process designed to remove spots or stains which remain in a
fabric after it has been subjected to the other processes of dry cleaning.
(`95 Code, § 117.055)
§ 117.056 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   License required. No person shall conduct, operate or maintain any dry
cleaning establishment in the village without first securing a license
therefor.
   (B)   Application. Applications for licenses required by division (A) of
this section shall be made in writing to the Village Clerk and shall be
referred to the Fire Chief. The Fire Chief shall investigate the premises
intended to be used, and shall report the result of the investigation to the
President and Board of Trustees before the issuance of a license. No such
license shall be issued to any person not complying with all the provisions of
this subchapter, with the provisions of the building code (
Chapter 150), the zoning code (
Chapter 156), and all ordinances relating to flammable liquids.
   (C)   Fee. The annual license fee shall be $50 and for a subdivision, $25.
(`95 Code, § 117.056) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.057 FIRE REGULATIONS.
   No dry cleaning establishment shall be operated in a frame building. Such
establishment shall be kept free from inflammable wastes so far as possible,
and it shall be unlawful to maintain or permit a stove or open flame of any
kind in the premises. Smoking in such premises is prohibited, and appropriate
signs to that effect shall be posted in conspicuous places in the
establishment.
(`95 Code, § 117.057) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.058 SANITARY STANDARDS.
   The premises must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and must be kept
free from rats, mice and vermin. No person afflicted with a contagious or
venereal disease shall be employed in any dry cleaning establishment.
(`95 Code, § 117.058) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.059 INSPECTION OF PREMISES.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police or other official
designated by the President and Board of Trustees to inspect or cause to be
inspected every establishment licensed under this subchapter, at least once
every six months. Any violations, of this or any other ordinance relating to
dry cleaners, premises or flammable liquids, shall be reported to the President
and Board of Trustees.
   (B)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall have the right to enter any
building or premises situated in the village and occupied by any dry cleaning
establishment, in order to examine the same and to determine whether or not the
building and premises, or any material, chemical or compound kept therein, or
used thereon, or any article or fabric dry cleaned, dyed, spotted or finished,
as received, used, kept, maintained or stored on the premises or building
conforms to the fire ordinances and regulations of the village or constitutes a
fire hazard in the village.
(`95 Code, § 117.059)
ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS
§ 117.070 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR. Includes any person engaged in the business of
installing or altering by contract, equipment and electrical appliances for the
utilization of electricity supplied by light, heat or power not including radio
apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sounds and signals, and not
including apparatus, conductors and other equipment installed for or by public
utilities, including common carriers, which are under the jurisdiction of the
Illinois Commerce Commission for use in their operation as public utilities.
The term ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR does not include employees employed by such
contractor to do or supervise such work.
(`95 Code, § 117.070)
§ 117.071 CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.
   (A)   Certificate required; application. No person shall engage in the
business of electrical contractor without having first secured a certificate of
registration therefor. Applications for such certificate shall be made to the
Village Clerk and a list of all contractors registered shall be given by the
Clerk to the Building Inspector.
   (B)   Fee; term. The annual fee for registering as an electrical contractor
shall be $25; provided, that on application made after the expiration of the
first six months of the register year, a certificate shall be issued upon the
payment of one-half this fee. The registration year shall correspond to the
license year.
(`95 Code, § 117.071) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.072 COMPLIANCE WITH ELECTRICAL CODE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person registered under the provisions of this
subchapter to install any electrical appliance, wiring or fixtures without
strict compliance with the provisions of this code or other ordinances relating
to such fixtures, and it shall be unlawful for any such person to do any work
without having obtained such permits as may be required.
(`95 Code, § 117.072) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.073 EXEMPTION FROM PAYMENT OF FEE.
   Any electrical contractor who is registered as such in any other city or
village in this state shall not be required to pay a fee for being registered
in the village; but every person doing business in the village as an electrical
contractor shall secure a certificate of registration. Such certificate shall
be issued without charge to electrical contractors registered as such under the
ordinances of another city or village in this state.
(`95 Code, § 117.073)
EXPRESSMEN AND DRAYMEN
§ 117.085 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   License required; application. It shall be unlawful for any person to
conduct the business of drayman, carter, trucker or expressman in the village
without first having obtained a license therefor. Applications for such
licenses shall be made to the Village Clerk, and shall designate thereon the
name of the licensee, the location of his or her business and the number of
vehicles intended to be used by him or her.
   (B)   Fee. The annual fee for the license required by division (A) of this
section shall be $25. Any licensee maintaining or using more than one vehicle
for the business shall pay an additional $10 for each additional vehicle.
(`95 Code, § 117.085) Penalty, see §
117.999
FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES
§ 117.095 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   License required. It shall be unlawful for any corporation or
association not incorporated under the laws of the state to engage in effecting
fire insurance in the village or to transact any business of fire insurance in
the village without fully complying with the provisions of this subchapter.
   (B)   Fee. Any corporation or association shall pay to the Village Treasurer
for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Fire Department, a sum of money
equal to 2% of the gross receipts each year received for premiums by any and
all agents of any such corporation or association or received as premiums in
any way for fire insurance policies on any property in the village. Such
payments shall be made for the year ending the July 1 of each year.
(`95 Code, § 117.095) (Ord. 75-14, passed - - ; Am. Ord. 82-16, passed 6-23-82)
Cross-reference:
   Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Board, see §§
32.145 et seq.
§ 117.096 ANNUAL REPORT REQUIRED.
   Every person acting as representative for or on behalf of any such company
or association shall, on or before the July 15 of each year, render to the
Village Treasurer a full, true and just account, verified by his or her oath,
of all premiums which have been received by him or her on behalf of the company
or association during the year ending the preceding July 1 on such fire
insurance policies.
(`95 Code, § 117.096)
§ 117.097 PAYMENT OF FEE.
   All payments under the provisions of this subchapter shall be made on or
before the July 15 following the termination of the year for which such
payments are due.
(`95 Code, § 117.097)
HOUSE MOVERS
§ 117.110 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   License required; application. It shall be unlawful to engage in the
business of house moving, razing or shoring without first having secured a
license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to
the Village Clerk.
   (B)   Fee. The annual fee for the licenses required by division (A) of this
section shall be $25.
(`95 Code, § 117.100) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.111 COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS.
   Persons licensed under this subchapter shall comply with all the provisions
of this code and other ordinances relating to the work being done, and must pay
the permit fee required for moving buildings, and must keep lights and warnings
maintained as is required by this code.
(`95 Code, § 117.111) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.112 INSPECTIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to make or cause to be made such
inspections as may be necessary to insure compliance with the provisions of
this subchapter.
(`95 Code, § 117.112)
§ 117.113 BOND REQUIRED.
   Every licensee under the provisions of this subchapter shall file with the
Village Clerk a bond in the sum of $5,000 with sureties to be approved by the
President and Board of Trustees conditioned to indemnify the village for any
loss, damage, or expense occasioned by it; by any act or failure to act of the
licensee, or by any failure of the licensee to comply with provisions of this
code or other ordinances relating to the business of house moving or moving
houses.
(`95 Code, § 117.113)
§ 117.114 PAVEMENT ALONG ROUTE TO BE PROTECTED.
   The pavement, of any street, alley or sidewalk on or along which any house
is moved shall be protected by two-inch planks along the route.
(`95 Code, § 117.114)
LAUNDRIES
§ 117.125 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   License required; application. No person shall operate or conduct a
laundry in the village without having first obtained a license therefor;
provided, that establishments licensed as dry cleaning establishments need not
obtain a laundry license in addition to the dry cleaning license. Application
for such license shall be made in writing to the Village Clerk and shall state
thereon the location intended to be occupied.
   (B)   Fee. The annual fee for laundry licenses shall be $50, and no license
shall be issued except on payment of the fee.
(`95 Code, § 117.125) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.126 SANITARY STANDARDS.
   Premises used for laundries must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
No refuse of any kind shall be permitted to accumulate on such premises; and
the premises must be kept free from rats, mice and vermin. It shall be unlawful
to employ any person afflicted with a venereal or any contagious disease in a
laundry.
(`95 Code, § 117.126) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.127 INSPECTION OF PREMISES.
   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police or other official designated by
the President and Board of Trustees to inspect or cause to be inspected every
establishment licensed under this subchapter at least once every six months.
Any violations under the terms of this subchapter which are discovered shall be
reported to the President and Board of Trustees.
(`95 Code, § 117.127)
MACHINE SHOPS
§ 117.135 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   MACHINE SHOP. Includes every workshop in which machines are made or metal
parts thereof are repaired, or where parts of machines or tools, implements,
gears, dies, screws or other metal articles are cut, filed, shaped or repaired
by means of a lathe or other machinery.
(`95 Code, § 117.135)
§ 117.136 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Required. No person shall conduct, operate or manage a machine shop in
the village without having first secured a license therefor; provided, that
this subchapter shall not be construed as requiring an additional license for
any class of machine shop specifically licensed under any other provisions of
this code or other ordinances of the village.
   (B)   Fee. The annual fee for a machine shop license shall be $25.
(`95 Code, § 117.136) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.137 HEALTH AND SANITARY REQUIREMENTS.
   No building, structure or part thereof shall be used for or in connection
with any machine shop in any way so as to endanger the health or property of
the employees or of the public; the owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or manager
of any such machine shops shall cause all floors or other surfaces around or
beneath any machine or work bench to be kept in good order and repair and shall
have suitable and convenient and sanitary receptacles for receiving wastes and
cloths used in and about the machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines
or parts thereof or which are intended for any other use. No person suffering
from any actively contagious or infectious disease shall be employed in or
about any machine shop where cutting compound or fluid is used. All such
cutting compound or fluid shall be kept free from infectious or harmful matter.
(`95 Code, § 117.137) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.138 INSPECTIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the Health Inspector to make or cause to be made
such inspections as may be necessary to insure compliance with the provisions
of this subchapter.
(`95 Code, § 117.138)
§ 117.139 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No machine shop shall be operated in the nighttime between the hours of 8:00
p.m. and 6:00 a.m. in any place in which a majority of the buildings within a
radius of 400 feet are used exclusively for residence purposes.
(`95 Code, § 117.139)
NURSING HOMES
§ 117.150 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   NURSING HOME. Any institution, place or family used for the reception or
care, for a longer period than 24 hours, of three or more children or infants
apart from their parents. A NURSING HOME is also any institution used for the
reception or care of persons who are dependent or not capable of properly
caring for themselves, and shall include homes for aged or infirm, orphan
asylums, refuges and shelters, and also boarding homes caring for three or more
women with their children when such children are less than 14 years of age.
(`95 Code, § 117.150)
§ 117.151 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   License required. It shall be unlawful for any person other than the
regularly constituted authorities of the United States, the county, the
village, or the state, or any association or institution for the care of
children which has been accredited, certified or licensed by the state,
pursuant to an act of the legislature, to regulate the treatment and control of
dependent, neglected and delinquent children, to open, conduct, manage or
maintain any homes, as defined in §
117.150, within the corporate limits of the village, without first obtaining a
license therefor as hereinafter provided.
   (B)   Application. Any person desiring a license required by division (A) of
this section shall make application in writing to the Village Clerk. Such
application shall conform to the general provisions of this code relating to
applications for licenses and shall state the location or proposed location of
the home, the purpose for which it is to be opened, conducted or maintained,
the accommodations for the inmates thereof, the nature and kind of care,
instruction or benefits given or proposed to be given therein, the name and
address of the officials or board of officials conducting, managing or
maintaining the home, the name of the superintendent or person in charge of the
home, the name and address of the chief physician, surgeon, or attending
physician or surgeon, or the names and addresses of the board of physicians or
surgeons attending therein if there is such a board.
   (C)   Investigation. It shall be the duty of the health officer, upon
presentation of the application required by division (B) of this section, to
make or cause to be made strict inquiry into the facts set out in such
application, and if upon inquiry and inspection he or she shall find that such
home complies with all provisions of this code and other ordinances and
statutes relating thereto, he or she shall recommend to the President and Board
of Trustees, that a license be issued.
   (D)   Fee. The license fee to be paid annually to the Village Collector for
the license required by this chapter shall be $25.
(`95 Code, § 117.151)
§ 117.152 STANDARDS FOR OPERATION.
   (A)   Floor space and ventilation. In every home defined in §
117.150, each room occupied or to be occupied by inmates shall be of such
dimensions as shall give each inmate not less than 400 cubic feet of air space.
Every such room shall have at least one window connecting with the external air
for each four beds. These windows shall be of such dimensions as shall secure
to each inmate at least 1,500 cubic feet of fresh air per hour by ventilation,
or in case the window shall not secure 1,500 cubic feet of fresh air per hour
by natural ventilation, then each room shall in addition thereto, be fitted
with such appliances for ventilation as shall secure to each inmate in his or
her room at least 1,500 cubic feet of fresh air per hour. Each bed shall have
at least 60 square feet of floor space, and in every room or dormitory
containing more than one bed the beds shall be so arranged as to leave a
passageway of not less than three feet horizontally on all sides of each bed.
   (B)   Health and sanitation. Each ward or wing in the home, as defined in §
117.150, shall have running water furnished in one or more places, either in
the ward or convenient thereto so that the same may be adequate and convenient
to the occupants thereof. The plumbing, water closets, bathrooms and other
sanitary appliances and equipment shall be constructed in accordance with the
provisions of
Chapter 110, General Business Licensing and other village ordinances relating
thereto. The floor of the cellar or basement in the building used as a home
shall be properly cemented so as to be watertight.
   (C)   Halls and fire escapes. The halls of each floor in a nursing home
shall be open to the external air with suitable windows, and shall have no room
or other obstruction at either end thereof, unless sufficient light and
ventilation is otherwise provided for such halls, and the building as a whole
shall be provided with adequate and proper fire escapes, stairways or inclines
for exist.
   (D)   Screens. All homes, including the culinary department, dining rooms,
laundry, laboratory, morgue and post-mortem rooms connected with the same shall
be equipped from May 15 to November 15 with doors, screens and other appliances
necessary for the exclusion of flies.
(`95 Code, § 117.152)
WEIGHTS AND MEASURES
§ 117.160 SCALES REGULATED.
   (A)   Every public weighmaster shall provide his or her own scale or scales,
which shall be approved by the Board of Trustees, and he or she shall keep them
adjusted and repaired at his or her own expense. They shall be inspected by the
Chief of Police, or by someone else, qualified to make such inspection
appointed by the Board of Trustees.
   (B)   Weighmasters and their deputies are entitled to weigh only on the
scale mentioned in their license and a new application for a new scale must be
made and the Village Clerk notified. If the location of the scale is changed an
application for such transfer of location must be made and approved.
(`95 Code, § 117.160) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.161 PUBLIC WEIGHMASTER; DUTIES.
   The public weighmaster or his or her deputy shall weigh all commodities
tendered for weighing at any reasonable time except on holidays and Sundays.
(`95 Code, § 117.161)
§ 117.162 CHARGES FOR WEIGHING.
   Public weighmasters when not the owner of the commodities being weighed by
him or her shall be entitled to charge a sum not in excess of $.10 for each and
every part of every load and part of load or less quantity when contained in
any vehicle, for any commodity or article weighed by him or her over such
scales.
(`95 Code, § 117.162)
§ 117.163 SEAL REQUIRED.
   Every weighmaster shall procure a seal, in form to be approved by the Board
of Trustees, which shall show his or her name, and shall stamp each certificate
issued by him or her under such seal.
(`95 Code, § 117.163)
§ 117.164 WEIGHT CERTIFICATE.
   (A)   Certificate; information.
      (1)   Each public weighmaster shall make out in triplicate a weight
certificate on each load weighed by him or her or his or her deputy containing
the following information:
         (a)   The commodity or article weighed;
         (b)   Name of weighmaster or deputy;
         (c)   Name of person, firm or corporation for whom weighing was done;
         (d)   Name of the driver of vehicle, or name of person bringing
material to be weighed to scales;
         (e)   Kind of vehicle;
         (f)   Address of consignee;
         (g)   Gross weight of vehicle and driver, or wagon, driver and horses;
         (h)   Tare weight of vehicle and driver, or wagon, horses and driver;
and
         (i)   Net weight of the article if not in vehicle.
      (2)   Any weighmaster shall not in any case state tare weight of the
vehicle until he or she has ascertained it himself or herself; except in cases
of a divided load.
   (B)   Copies. Each weighmaster must keep a copy of every certificate which
shall be numbered, and shall constitute the record of his or her business. Each
certificate must be kept for a period of at least two years, and be open to the
inspection of the Chief of Police.
(`95 Code, § 117.164)
§ 117.165 ONLY PUBLIC WEIGHMASTER TO CHARGE FOR WEIGHING.
   No one except a public weighmaster licensed under this chapter shall weigh
any article for a fee or reward, and no one shall use or keep a scale in any
public place, street or alley without permission to do so from the Board of
Trustees.
(`95 Code, § 117.165)
§ 117.166 ISSUANCE OF FALSE WEIGHT CERTIFICATE.
   No public weighmaster shall issue a certificate giving a false weight for
the article weighed, and upon conviction of false weight certificate issuance,
he or she shall be fined as set forth in §
117.999.
(`95 Code, § 117.166) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.167 PERSON REQUESTING FALSE WEIGHT CERTIFICATE PROHIBITED.
   Any person requesting a false certificate from any public weighmaster shall
be fined as set forth in §
117.999.
(`95 Code, § 117.167) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.168 WEIGHT CERTIFICATE TO BE GIVEN TO PURCHASER.
   A copy of such weight certificate shall be delivered to the purchaser, or if
there is at the place of delivery no one to receive such delivery, shall be
posted in a conspicuous place at the place of delivery before such article or
commodity so weighed shall be unloaded. The remaining copy shall be retained by
the seller.
(`95 Code, § 117.168)
§ 117.169 ALTERATION OF CERTIFICATE PROHIBITED.
   No person shall alter any such certificate or attempt to use it for any load
other than the one for which it was issued.
(`95 Code, § 117.169) Penalty, see §
117.999
§ 117.170 CONDITIONS ON REWEIGHING.
   Any person upon request to the Chief of Police shall be permitted to take
his or her load to another scale for the purpose of reweighing the load but
upon the following conditions:
   (A)   Gross load shall be weighed immediately and tare weight shall be
ascertained immediately after delivery of the load; and
   (B)   The reweighing must take place on a scale approved by the Chief of
Police.
(`95 Code, § 117.170)
§ 117.171 REWEIGHING COMMODITIES OWNED BY WEIGHMASTER.
   Upon request to the Chief of Police, any purchaser of goods owned or sold by
the public weighmaster and weighed by him or her, may take the goods under the
supervision of the public weighmaster to another scale approved by the Chief of
Police and there reweigh the same.
(`95 Code, § 117.171)
§ 117.172 NET WEIGHT DEFINED.
   When any commodity, produce or article is sold or is subject to the public
weighmaster's weights, the net weight shown in the weight certificate issued by
such weighmaster shall be taken to be the true weight of the same, subject to
the right of reweighing. NET WEIGHT  within the meaning of this subchapter
shall be the actual weight of the commodity, produce or article excluding the
weight of the vehicle, if any, in which it is loaded, and excluding the weight
of the horse and driver of such vehicle, or either of them, as the case may be,
if such horse and driver or either of them be weighed as part of the tare
weight.
(`95 Code, § 117.172)
§ 117.173 WEIGHMASTER PERMITTED TO WEIGH OWN COMMODITIES.
   Nothing in this subchapter shall prevent the public weighmaster from
engaging in the business of selling any article, commodity or produce which is
ordinarily delivered by vehicle or of weighing the same.
(`95 Code, § 117.173)
§ 117.174 WEIGHMASTER.
   (A)   Appointment. Any person owning a scale suitable for weighing any
commodity, produce or articles of merchandise in load lots, when contained in
any wagon, auto truck or other vehicle, or in any quantity when not contained
in any wagon, auto truck or load, lots shall be eligible for appointment as a
public weighmaster in the village after complying with the provisions of this
subchapter.
   (B)   Application; bond; license.
      (1)   Every applicant for a license as a public weighmaster, shall file
an application in writing conforming to the requirements of
Chapter 110, General Business Licensing, and set forth the location of the
place of business for which such license is requested. Such application shall
also contain the following agreement:
“The applicant hereby agrees and consents as a condition of the issuance of the
license hereunder, that in case the applicant as a public weighmaster weighs
any load lot of any commodity, procures an article of merchandise sold in load
lots, by weight, sold or delivered by the applicant or by any person directly
or indirectly interested with the applicant in the operation of the public
scale of the applicant, the Chief of Police, or the purchaser or consignee
shall have the right to reweigh any such article of merchandise, produce or
other load as provided in this subchapter. This condition is accepted by the
applicant with the understanding that same shall, upon the issuance of a
license hereunder at once become binding upon him.”
      (2)   Such applicant shall also execute a bond and present it with his or
her application to the village in the sum of $2,000, with such sureties as may
be approved by the President and the Board of Trustees, conditioned upon the
duties of public weighmaster, and for the payment of any fines which may be
imposed upon him or her for violation of any such duties. Upon compliance with
these conditions and upon payment of the sum of $10 as an annual license fee,
he or she may be issued a license authorizing him or her to act as a public
weighmaster.
      (3)   The license so issued shall contain apt words indicating that the
license is issued subject to the conditions and agreements herein set forth,
and any person violating any of these conditions shall be liable to a penalty
of $50, in addition to any other penalty prescribed by law.
   (C)   Deputy weighmaster. Each public weighmaster shall have the power to
appoint all necessary deputies to attend such weights and scales, such deputies
to furnish a bond in the same amount as the public weighmaster and conditioned
in the same manner. Each deputy weighmaster must pay an annual fee of $5. Each
public weighmaster shall be answerable for all acts of the deputy weighmaster
but the weighmaster's responsibility shall not relieve the deputy's liability
for his or her own acts. The weighmaster may cancel such appointment at any
time but he or she must notify the Village Clerk of such cancellation.
(`95 Code, § 117.174)
PAYDAY LENDING INSTITUTIONS
§ 117.185 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CHECK(S). Shall include a check, draft, money order, or personal money
order.
   DEFERRED DEPOSIT TRANSACTION. Shall mean a transaction in which a check
casher advances cash to a consumer against a personal check made out to the
check casher for the amount advanced, less a fee, and the check casher then
holds and does not deposit the personal check in the check casher's account for
a period of three days or more.
   INTEREST BEARING LOAN. An interest bearing loan shall be a loan in which
interest is charged upon the principal amount borrowed.
   PAYDAY LENDING INSTITUTION. Shall mean a person that routinely and
customarily engages in deferred deposit transactions or payday loan
transactions.
   PAYDAY LOAN TRANSACTION. Shall mean any transaction in which a person loans
money to a borrower and the loan becomes due and payable upon the next payday
of the borrower or any member of the borrower's immediate family.
   PERSON. Shall mean an individual, partnership, an association, a trust, a
corporation, or any other legal entity.
   SHORT-TERM LOAN. Shall mean a loan for a term of not more than 30 days.
(Ord. 02-23, passed 6-19-02)
§ 117.186 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to act as a payday loan institution
without first obtaining a payday loan license under this subchapter.
(Ord. 02-23, passed 6-19-02)
§ 117.187 APPLICATION.
   (A)   An application for a payday loan license, as provided for in this
subchapter, shall be made to the Village President in writing, signed by the
applicant if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof if a
corporation or other legal entity, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall
contain the following statements and information:
      (1)   The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an
individual; in the case of a co-partnership, the persons who are entitled to a
share in the profits thereof; and in the case of a corporation, the objects for
which organized, the names and addresses of the officers and directors, and if
a majority interest in the stock of such corporation is owned by one person or
his or her nominee, the name and address of such person;
      (2)   The citizenship of the applicant, his or her place of birth, and if
a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his or her naturalization;
      (3)   The character of business of the applicant and, in the case of a
corporation, the objects for which it was formed, the length of time the
applicant in question has been in business of that character, or in the case of
a corporation, the date when its charter was issued;
      (4)   Three reference letters, one of which must be from a financial
institution;
      (5)   A credit report for the business and all principals of the business
or, if an individual, for the individual; and if a co-partnership, for all
partners;
      (6)   A criminal record report from the state police of the state of
residence for each owner, partner, board member, officer and any individual who
will be managing the Bellwood location;
      (7)   A statement of whether the applicant has made an application for a
similar or other license on premises other than those described in his or her
application, and the disposition of the application;
      (8)   A CPA prepared, audited or reviewed financial statement showing at
least $100,000 net worth with $50,000 in liquid assets for the applicant;
      (9)   The name of the person who will be managing the business. The
applicant must show a minimum of two years of finance related experience for
anyone who will be managing a Bellwood location;
      (10)   A business resume for the manager, owner, partners, and all other
officers and a statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of
the State of Illinois or of the United States of any of the provisions of this
code in the conduct of the business.
   (B)   The applicant shall file with the Village President a the time of the
application, two copies of a list of names and residences of all board member,
and similarly file within ten days of the election of any additional member of
his or her name and address; and provided that its affairs and management are
conducted by a board of directors, executive committee or similar body chosen
by the members at their annual meeting, a list of names and residences of its
board of directors, executive committee members or other members of the
governing body.
(Ord. 02-23, passed 6-19-02)
§ 117.188 RESTRICTIONS ON ISSUANCE.
   (A)   No license, as provided in this subchapter, shall be issued to:
      (1)   A person who is not a resident of the Village;
      (2)   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the
community in which he or she resides;
      (3)   A person who is not a resident of the United States;
      (4)   A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of the
state;
      (5)   A person who has been convicted of pandering or crime or
misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality;
      (6)   A person whose license under this subchapter has been revoked for
cause;
      (7)   A co-partnership, unless all of the members of such co-partnership
shall be qualified to obtain a license;
      (8)   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any
stockholder or stockholders holding in the aggregate more than 5% of the stock
of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for
any reason other than citizenship and residence within the village.
      (9)   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless the manager or agent possess the same qualifications required of the
licensee;
      (10)   A person or business who cannot present a CPA prepared, audited or
reviewed financial statement showing at least $100,000 net worth with $50,000
in liquid assets;
      (11)   A person who does not have a strong financial background;
      (12)   A person that has a poor credit rating history;
      (13)   A person who has been convicted of any crime involving dishonesty.
   (B)   The Comptroller shall conduct an investigation of each applicant to
determine financial responsibility, business experience, character and general
fitness of the applicant. The Comptroller may request any additional
documentation or information needed to conduct a thorough investigation.
(Ord. 02-23, passed 6-19-02)
§ 117.189 TERMINATION DATE.
   Each payday loan license, as provided in this subchapter, shall terminate on
April 30 next following the date of issuance.
(Ord. 02-23, passed 6-19-02)
§ 117.190 RENEWAL OF LICENSE.
   The holder of any payday loan license issued under this subchapter may renew
the license at the expiration thereof; provided, that he or she has been
qualified to receive a license and that he or she and the business qualify for
a license under this subchapter. The renewal privilege provided for herein
shall not be construed as vested right.
§ 117.191 FEES.
   Every person shall pay a license fee of $200 per year, which sum shall be
paid at the time the applicant files an application for a payday loan license
with the village.
(Ord. 02-23, passed 6-19-02)
§ 117.192 DISPOSITION OF FEES.
   All fees paid under this subchapter shall be paid to the Village President
at the time application for a license under this subchapter is made, and shall
be forthwith turned over to the Treasurer. In the event that any license
applied for is denied, the fee shall be returned to the applicant. If the
license is granted, the fee shall be deposited in a general corporate fund, or
in such other fund as shall have been designated by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 02-23, passed 6-19-02)
§ 117.193 RECORD OF LICENSES TO BE KEPT.
   The Village President shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of
all payday loan licenses issued by him or her under this subchapter.
(Ord. 02-23, passed 6-19-02)
§ 117.194 VIOLATIONS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in payday loan transactions
without a payday loan license required under this chapter.
(Ord. 02-23, passed 6-19-02)
§ 117.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter for which another
penalty is not already herein provided, shall be subject to the penalty
provisions of $
10.99.
   (B)   Any person violating the provisions of §§
117.040 et seq., shall be subject to citation issued by the Health Officer with
a minimum fine of $10 for each violation.
(Ord. 79-12, passed 12-12-79)
   (C)   Any person violating the provisions of §§
117.150 et seq., shall be fined not less than $10 nor more than $1,000 for
every offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during
or on which a violation occurs or continues. Provided, that in the event of a
conviction of any person for a violation of any of the provisions of §§
117.150 et seq. relating to the safety and accommodations of inmates it shall
be the duty of the Health Officer to close such home and to cause its vacation
pending the repairs, alteration or additions necessary to make it safe and
proper for the occupancy of its inmates and to make it comply with the terms of
this chapter.
   (D)   Any person violating the provisions of §
117.166, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than
$1,000, and the Board of Trustees may at its discretion revoke his or her
license.
   (E)   Any person violating the provisions of §
117.167, shall be fined not less than $10 nor more than $1,000 for each
offense.
(`95 Code, § 117.999)
CHAPTER 118: PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS
Section
Itinerant Merchants
   
118.01   Definition
   
118.02   License provisions
Peddlers and Hawkers
   
118.10   License provisions
   
118.11   Fraud and misrepresentation prohibited; revocation of license
Solicitors
   
118.20   Definitions
   
118.21   Certificate of registration provisions

ITINERANT MERCHANTS
§ 118.01 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ITINERANT MERCHANT. Any merchant engaging or intending to engage in business
as a merchant in the village for a period of time not exceeding 100 days.
Peddlers shall not be construed as ITINERANT MERCHANTS.
(`95 Code, § 118.01)
§ 118.02 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   License required. It shall be unlawful for any person to do business
as an itinerant merchant without having first secured a license.
   (B)   Application. Every application for the license required by division
(A) of this section shall set forth the commodities to be sold, and the place
intended to be occupied or used for the business.
   (C)   Fee. The fee for the license required by division (A) of this section
shall be $25 per month and $5 for one day.
(`95 Code, § 118.02)
PEDDLERS AND HAWKERS
§ 118.10 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   License required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the
business of a hawker or peddler of any merchandise, article or thing, without
first having obtained a license therefor.
   (B)   Application. Application for the license pursuant to this subchapter
shall be made to the Village Clerk, and shall state thereon the number of
vehicles, if any, intended to be used; the kind of merchandise to be peddled
and the permanent address of the peddler.
   (C)   Fee. The fee for a peddler's or hawker's license shall be $75 for an
annual license; $30 for a monthly license and $2 for a daily license.
(`95 Code, § 118.10) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 118.11 FRAUD AND MISREPRESENTATION PROHIBITED; REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   Any licensed peddler or hawker who shall be guilty of any fraud, cheating or
misrepresentation, whether through himself or herself or through an employee,
while acting as a peddler in the village, or who shall barter, sell or peddle
any goods, wares or merchandise other than those specified in his or her
application for a license shall be punished as provided by §
10.99, and the President may revoke his or her license for such offense.
(`95 Code, § 118.11) Penalty, see §
10.99
SOLICITORS
§ 118.20 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   APPLICANT. Each person who engages in soliciting (as defined below in this
section) for commercial purposes; or, in the case of a charitable or nonprofit
organization, a sponsoring adult who shall be liable for all acts of all
persons soliciting or purporting to solicit for the organization.
   REGISTERED SOLICITOR. Any person who has obtained a valid certificate of
registration as hereinafter provided, and which certificate is in the
possession of the solicitor on his or her person while engaged in soliciting.
   RESIDENCE. Every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by
one or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure.
   SOLICITING. Any one or more of the following activities whether for
commercial purposes, or for charitable purposes, or the benefit of a nonprofit
organization:
      (1)   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares,
merchandise, foodstuffs, service, of any kind, character or description
whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever;
      (2)   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase
of insurance of any type, kind or character;
      (3)   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals,
newspapers and every other type or kind of publication; or
      (4)   Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any
other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit
organization, association, corporation or project.
(`95 Code, § 118.20) (Ord. 70-5, passed - - ; Am. Ord. 8-34, passed 5-14-08 )
§ 118.21 CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Certificate required. Every person desiring to engage in soliciting as
defined in §
118.20, for commercial purposes; and every charitable organization or nonprofit
organization or association desiring to engage in soliciting, as defined in §
118.20, is hereby required to make written application for a certificate of
registration as herein after provided.
   (B)   Application.  
      (1)   Application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a
form provided by the Chief of Police of this village and filed with such Chief.
The applicant shall truthfully state in full the information requested on the
application, to wit for every person engaged in soliciting for commercial
purposes and for the sponsoring person for every charitable or nonprofit
organization:
         (a)   Name and address of present place of residence and length of
residence at such address; also business address if other than residence
address; also Social Security Number;
         (b)   Address and place of residence during the past three years if
other than present address;
         (c)   Age of applicant and marital status; and, if married, the name
of spouse;
         (d)   Physical description of the applicant;
         (e)   Name and address of the person whom the applicant is employed by
or represents; and the length of time of such employment of representation;
         (f)   Name and address of employer during the past three years if
other than the present employer;
         (g)   Description sufficient for identification of the subject matter
of the soliciting which the applicant will engage in;
         (h)   Period of time for which the certificate is applied for;
         (i)   The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous
application for the certificate under this subchapter, if any;
         (j)   Whether a certificate of registration issued to the applicant
under this subchapter has ever been revoked;
         (k)   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of
any of the provisions of this subchapter or the ordinance of any other state
municipality regulating soliciting;
         (l)   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission
of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or federal law of
the United States; and,
         (m)   Proof of commercial general liability insurance; and
         (n)   Such additional information as the Chief of Police may deem
necessary to process the application.
      (2)   All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in
connection therewith shall be under oath.
      (3)   The Chief of Police shall require every applicant to submit to
fingerprinting by the Police Department of this village in connection with the
application for certificate. A fee of $5 to cover the costs of fingerprinting
and background checks shall be paid by every applicant.
      (4)   The Chief of Police shall cause to be kept in his or her office an
accurate record of every application received and acted upon together with all
other information and data pertaining thereto and all certificates of
registration issued under the provisions of this subchapter, and of the denial
of applications. Applications for certificates shall be numbered in consecutive
order as filed, and every certificate issued, and any renewal thereof, shall be
identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was
issued.
      (5)   No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who
has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state or
any other state or federal law of the United States, within five years of the
date of the application; nor to any person who has been convicted of a
violation of any of the provisions of this subchapter, nor to any person whose
certificate of registration issued hereunder has previously been revoked as
herein provided.
   (C)   Denial; issuance; revocation.  
      (1)   The Chief of Police, after consideration of the application and all
information obtained relative thereto, shall deny the application if the
applicant does not posses the qualifications for such certificate as herein
required, and that the issuance of a certificate of registration to the
applicant would not be in accord with the intent and purpose of this
subchapter. Endorsement shall be made by the Chief of Police upon the
application of the denial of the application. When the applicant is found to be
fully qualified, the certificate of registration shall be issued forthwith.
      (2)   Any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall be revoked
by the Chief of Police if the holder of the certificate is convicted of a
violation of any of the provisions of this subchapter, or has made a false
material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for
the issuance of a certificate of registration under the terms of this
subchapter. Immediately upon such revocation written notice thereof shall be
given by the Chief of Police to the holder of the certificate in person or by
certified U.S. mail addressed to his or her residence address set forth in the
application.
      (3)   Immediately upon the giving of such notice the certificate of
registration shall become null and void.
      (4)   The certificate of registration shall state the expiration date
thereof.
(`95 Code, § 118.21) (Ord. 70-5, passed - - ; Am. Ord. 8-34, passed 5-14-08 )
Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 118.22 RESIDENCE TO DETERMINE WHETHER SOLICITORS TO BE INVITED; NOTICE.
   (A)   It is hereby declared to be the policy of the governing body of this
village that occupants of the residences in this village shall make the
determination of whether solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited to their
respective residence. If no determination is made as is provided in division
(B) of this section, then in that event, registration is not required.
   (B)   Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided
by the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this subchapter, shall
comply with this division (B). Notice of the determination by the occupant of
giving invitation to solicitors, or the refusal of invitation to solicitors, to
any residence shall be given in the manner following:
      (1)    A weatherproof decal or card shall be exhibited upon or near the
main entrance door to the residence, indicating the determination by the
occupant, containing the applicable words, as follows:
   “ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED IN
   BELLWOOD INVITED”
   or
   “NO SOLICITORS INVITED”
      (2)   The letters shall be at least one-quarter inch in height. For the
purpose of uniformity the cards shall be provided by the Chief of Police to
persons requesting, at the cost thereof.
      (3)   Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any
solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the
information contained thereon.
(`95 Code, § 118.22) (Ord. 70-5, passed - - ; Am. Ord. 8-34, passed 5-14-08 )
§ 118.23 DUTY OF SOLICITORS.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going onto any premises
in the municipality upon which a residence as herein defined is located to
first examine the notice provided for in §
118.22(B), if any is attached, and be governed by the statement contained on
the notice. If the notice states “ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED IN BELLWOOD
INVITED,” then the solicitor not possessing a valid certificate of registration
as herein provided shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises;
and if the notice states “NO SOLICITORS INVITED,” then the solicitor, whether
registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises.
   (B)   Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether
invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when
requested to do so by the occupant.
(`95 Code, § 118.23) (Ord. 70-5, passed - -  ; Am. Ord. 8-34, passed 5-14-08 )
§ 118.24 UNINVITED SOLICITATION PROHIBITED.
   It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any
person to go upon any premises and ring the door bell upon or near any door, or
create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the
occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the
occupant thereof and engage in soliciting as herein defined, in defiance of the
notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of §
118.22(B).
(`95 Code, § 118.24) (Ord. 70-5, passed - -  ; Am. Ord. 8-34, passed 5-14-08 )
Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 118.25 TIME RESTRICTED.
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for
any person, whether registered under this subchapter or not, to go upon any
premises and ring the door bell upon or near any door of a residence located
thereon, or rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner
calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the
purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof, and engage in
soliciting as herein defined, prior to 10:00 a.m. or after 7:00 p.m. of any
day, Monday through Saturday, or at any time on a Sunday or on a state or
national holiday.
(`95 Code, § 118.25) (Ord. 70-5, passed - - ; Am. Ord. 8-34, passed 5-14-08 )
Penalty, see §
10.99
